PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that . . .

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the disallowance of entertainment expenses are keys to the financing of the Government's income tax reductions on 1 December. The Government will collect $575m from the fringe benefits tax in a full financial year, over $300m from the disallowance of entertainment expenses and further revenues from the capital gains tax. Those revenues are vital components in the financing of the substantial personal income tax reductions beginning on 1 December this year. Since November 1984 this Government has cut personal income tax substantially. For example, a person with a taxable income of $400 weekly will have received tax reductions of $12.70 weekly after the December tax cuts and a person with a taxable income of $300 weekly will have received personal income tax reductions of $11.35 weekly from 1 December.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the Government's taxation changes no Australian will pay more than half of his or her extra income in taxation. The top marginal tax rate of 49c in the dollar will ensure that no Australian will pay more than half his or her extra income in the form of income tax. This is clear proof of the Hawke Government's commitment to lower taxation-two rounds of personal income tax reductions in two years.
I would like to consider the record of the former Treasurer, the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in taxation. Mr Howard was recently quoted in the Adelaide News as saying:
I think the high marginal rates of tax are increasingly out of line with the need for more incentive in our tax system.

Yet after five years as Treasurer, from 1978 to 1982, Mr Howard left a top marginal rate of income tax of 60c in the dollar. That was his record. Under Labor, from 1 July 1987, after the final instalment of the income tax reductions, the top marginal rate will be not 60c or 50c in the dollar, but 49c in the dollar. Yet Mr Howard has the gall to claim that the marginal tax rates under this Government are too high. Mr Howard was never good at making figures stick, but even this simple piece of arithmetic seems to have escaped him. Under the Fraser-Howard coalition Government, the top marginal tax rate was 60c in the dollar. Under the Hawke Labor Government, the top marginal tax rate will be 49c in the dollar.

At the bottom of the income tax scale, the lowest income bracket, the best Mr Howard could achieve as Treasurer was a marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar. That was his record. As a result of Labor's tax package, the bottom marginal tax rate will not be 30c or 25c in the dollar. It will be 24c in the dollar-6c below the lowest marginal tax rate that Mr Howard could deliver in five years as Treasurer. One can draw only one conclusion from these figures, which is that the Liberal Party is the high tax party of Australia. The Liberal Party talks about low taxes but could never deliver the goods when in office.

What are the coalition's tax policies? We asked Senator Messner last night. He said that they would be forthcoming, but he was not specific about when we would see them. We do not know what they are. Mr Howard refuses to give any details. Trying to obtain firm policy commitments from the Opposition is like trying to get blood out of a stone. The Opposition ducks and weaves when any questions are asked about the specific details of its taxation policies. All we hear from Mr Howard on taxation is a lot of vague rhetoric. But rhetoric is no substitute for hard policies. The Opposition is attempting to con the Australian people in the matter of taxation.

Mr Howard's only concession to his honest John title is his consistent support for indirect taxes. When Mr Howard was Treasurer, he showed a liking for increasing indirect taxes very sharply. For example, in the 1981 Budget, Mr Howard, as Treasurer, increased sales tax on all products by 2 1/2 percentage points. He introduced sales tax on a range of goods for the first time. In one financial year, Mr Howard increased total Commonwealth revenue from sales taxes by an incredible 35 per cent. There was a 35 per cent growth in indirect tax revenue in one year. But he was not satisfied with that. He repeated it in his 1982 Budget. In that Budget he again increased all sales tax rates by 2 1/2 percentage points. In that Budget, the 1982 Budget, he further increased sales tax revenue, making an extra increase in total collections by the Commonwealth of 27 per cent. That was Mr Howard's record-support for indirect taxation, with a 66 per cent compound increase in sales tax revenue in just two financial years. Mr Howard was a high tax Treasurer. That is the record. He could not lower personal income tax rates, but he had little trouble in increasing sales tax rates by a massive 5 percentage points across the board in two years. He effectively trebled the pre-existing 2 1/2 per cent rate to 7 1/2 per cent in two Budgets. Mr Howard and his colleagues remain committed to the idea of extending and increasing indirect taxes, which would have horrifying inflationary consequences.

The Hawke Government's tax reform package has restored progressivity to the tax system. Once again the tax system has been based on the principle of an individual's capacity to pay. The Hawke Government will redistribute the tax burden from middle and low income earners. This is being done by closing the tax loopholes and by clamping down on the tax avoiders and evaders through such devices as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the disallowance of entertainment expenses. In those ways this Government is closing loopholes and is cracking down on avoidance and evasion in the community, thereby creating a fairer and more equitable taxation system in Australia. The revenue from the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, and from the disallowance of entertainment expenses, will finance the substantial personal income tax reductions to be given on 1 December.

Those tax cuts will be in the form of an increase in the tax free threshold and very substantial reductions in marginal tax rates. Those marginal tax rates that are being reduced have nothing to do with inflationary taxation. It is an absolute nonsense for Senator Messner to sit there and parrot off about inflation and try to deny the fact that this Government is cutting the top marginal tax rate from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. The middle tax rate is going down from 46c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar. That has nothing to do with inflation. They are very real and meaningful cuts in marginal tax rates and in combination with the increase in the tax free threshold to $5,100, which is something that the Liberal Party, while in office, could never achieve, this Government is going to deliver very substantial reductions in personal income tax from 1 December. As I indicated earlier, under this Government, those reductions over a two-year period will amount to some $12.70 per week for a person on $400 a week taxable income. They are very substantial reductions in personal income tax which illustrate that this Government can deliver the goods in reducing taxation for ordinary Australians and making those in the privileged parts of the community pay their fair share of the Australian taxation burden.

Mr Howard, as Treasurer, allowed the tax system to become increasingly regressive. Under Mr Howard and the Liberals, the Australian tax system fell into disrespect. That is the bottom line of it all. Under Mr Howard, the tax system rewarded a petty criminal obsession with tax fraud and evasion. They are the facts. They are the records of the late 1970s in Australia. Under Mr Howard more of the Australian tax burden was shuffled on to middle and low income earners. The proportion of tax receipts from pay as you earn taxpayers rose, while receipts fell from other income earners.

Let us look at the Opposition's rhetoric. Despite all the Opposition's loud talk about cutting taxes, in five Budgets Mr Howard was not able to make substantial reductions to personal income tax or reduce the overall taxation burden. In fact, under Mr Howard as Treasurer-the figures show this very clearly in the Budget Papers-the proportion of gross domestic product going in taxation rose significantly.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you've got the highest proportion ever.

—Senator Messner should look at Mr Howard's record. The trend started under Mr Howard and the proportion of gross domestic product going in taxation at the end of his period as Treasurer was almost 2 percentage points above the share at the beginning of his period as Treasurer. Senator Messner should read the figures in the Budget Papers. Despite that record and despite the ratio of taxation to gross domestic product rising over the five years of Mr Howard's stewardship of the Australian Treasury, the Opposition continues to parrot the line that it is a low tax party. That is the myth it is trying to perpetrate in the community. The Opposition has no tax credibility. It could not reduce taxation when it was in office. Its present tax commitments combine irresponsible pork barrelling with a string of tired cliches. That is in stark contrast with this Government's real reforms of the Australian taxation system. Those reforms are very real and will contribute to a more equitable Australian society. They will boost economic efficiency and they will underpin the restructuring of the Australian economy. The reforms deserve support for those very important reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Medicare Levy Bill 1986. I will confine my remarks to the three tax Bills and my colleague Senator Powell will comment later on the Medicare Levy Bill. In the three tax Bills we have at last the much publicised Government tax cuts which are part of the whole tax reform package. They are supposedly the icing on the cake for taxpayers after the imposition of the fringe benefits tax and tax increases in other areas, such as the capital gains tax. The tax cuts supposedly demonstrate the Government's commitment to reducing the tax burden on ordinary Australians. Let us remember the rationale for the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes. It was to spread the tax burden more equitably so that ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers would have some of the burden of high levels of income tax lifted from their shoulders.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us see first what is the taxation burden on the shoulders of average Australians. There is no illusion about it; there is an enormous income tax burden on their shoulders. The PAYE taxpayer has really been clobbered over the last 15 years as the figures eloquently demonstrate. In 1970-71 PAYE tax collections made up only 33.7 per cent of total Commonwealth tax collections. By 1986 that 33.7 per cent had risen to 45.5 per cent-over 16 years. So there is an enormous burden on the backs of average Australians to raise the big slice of the revenue the Government needs to govern this country. The ordinary person-the worker, the self-employed person, the small business person-is being progressively slugged by an unfair tax system. Reform was essential. There is no doubt about that.

Let us look at what has happened to tax rates at about the level of average weekly earnings. In 1955-56 average taxpayers faced marginal and average tax rates of 19 per cent and 10 per cent respectively. Today the corresponding figures are 46 per cent and 25 per cent. The marginal rate on the average income level is 46 per cent and the average level of average weekly earnings paid in tax is 25 per cent. One-quarter of the income goes in tax and the marginal rate is a massive 46 per cent. That marginal rate was designed to catch the millionaire 20 or so years ago.

I turn now to Federal tax raisings. There has been a lot of debate about whether this Government is in fact the highest tax raising government in history. The facts are these: Federal tax raisings have increased from 24.6 per cent of gross domestic product under Fraser to 25.5 per cent of GDP at present, in spite of the trilogy and in spite of tax cuts. So I say to Senator Messner that the figures bear out the claim that the present Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on what you assess when you do that.

—I must qualify that statement later in my remarks and I will do so. The Australian Democrats know, as every thinking Australian knows, that we cannot have real tax reform in this country until we have tax indexation. It is absolutely essential that we remove the tax by stealth known in the jargon as bracket creep. If we are to restore incentive to average Australians, it is absolutely essential that income tax rates be indexed every year to take account of inflation. If we do not do that, tax reform becomes meaningless. I will demonstrate what has happened to the tax cuts as a result of inflation since the Government first announced that we were to get them. Despite the Government's tax cuts, the PAYE taxpayer will contribute the same proportion of total tax in 1986-87 as he did in 1985-86. This legislation will ensure that there are tax cuts, but because of inflation, there will be no reduction in the amount of money that the average Australian will pay. There will be no real tax cuts, despite the claims of a $1.5 billion tax a cut in 1986-87 and a $4.5 billion tax cut in 1987-88.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have worked out an alternative, fairer system of income tax. This would involve tax indexation and a progressive rate of increase in the marginal rates of taxation from the threshold up to a maximum rate of 49 per cent. It is possible to eliminate these larger jumps in the marginal rate of taxation. If that were done, we could have a progressive rate of taxation, up to 49 per cent, which was streamlined and did not involve these enormous increases in tax as one receives wage or salary increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that revenue neutral?

—It is not quite revenue neutral, but it has been costed in our alternative Budget. I do not have the figure with me. It is certainly well within the restrictions of a responsible Budget, and one that keeps the deficit within bounds. At the end of my remarks I will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading which indicates that the Government should be condemned for not allowing indexation of personal income tax rates, which has allowed inflationary factors virtually to neutralise the Government's tax cuts. I hope the Opposition will support us in that regard. The amendment also condemns the Government for the very minor reductions in the marginal rate of tax at the level of the average income earner. That is the critical issue in tax reform in this country. Until those two points are addressed, we will not have real tax reform, as we should have, if we are to restore incentive to effort in Australia. I will be very interested to hear what the Opposition has to say about those amendments of the Democrats. I hope it will support us, and that it will foreshadow that, if it does form a government in the future, it will be responsible in regard to personal income tax reform in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's tax reform is far from satisfactory. But it is clearly preferable to the alternative offered by the Opposition, which is no tax reform at all. At least, that is the most we can make of it so far.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just have patience.

—I will talk about patience now. I was absolutely appalled last evening to hear Senator Messner castigate the Commissioner of Taxation for saying that some sort of fringe benefits tax is necessary. The Opposition criticised the Commissioner of Taxation for saying that, but it is not prepared to say what it will do. That is completely and absolutely irresponsible. Any thinking Australian knows that if one neutralises the fringe benefits tax, if one has no fringe benefits tax, one will open the system to the greatest tax rorts that this country has ever seen. We must have some control over fringe benefits if we are not to have virtually the whole taxing system in chaos. The Opposition has said it will neutralise the fringe benefits tax if it forms a government. It has not told us what it will do about fringe benefits, and how it will stop any rorts in this area. But it is not backward in criticising a hard working and, as far as I am aware, very efficient Commissioner of Taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has had a good look at the tax reform package in the United States of America and it is not backward in pointing out the fact that the top marginal rate of tax in the United States of America is 33 per cent against our 49 per cent. It is not backward in pointing out that for an income of $30,000 a year in Australia the marginal tax rate is 40 per cent and in the United States it is a mere 15 per cent. To carry the comparisons a little further, for an average income level of $35,000 a year-that is not a high salary-Australia's marginal tax rate is 49 per cent and in the United States it is still 15 per cent. For a comparatively high salary by Australian standards, $62,000 a year, our marginal tax rate is still 49 per cent, and in the United States it is only 28 per cent rising to a maximum of 33 per cent.

The explanation of why the United States can afford a top marginal rate of tax of 33 per cent lies in the different tax mix operating in the United States and Australia. To put some responsibility into this whole tax debate, we should look carefully at what goes on in the United States of America. It is all very well to say that it has a top marginal tax rate of 33 per cent, but let us look at what else is taxed in the United States. First, it has a broadly based consumption tax-sales tax-which operates at a State level and raises a large amount of revenue for the State governments. Secondly, the Federal Government collects social security contributions at 7.2 per cent, on top of income tax. The nearest equivalent we have in Australia is the Medicare levy, which the Government proposes to increase to 1.25 per cent of earnings.

Thirdly, in the United States-this is very important, and I hope Senator Messner will listen-a capital gains tax is levied at the maximum rate of 33 per cent for individuals and 34 per cent for companies. However, unlike Australia, it makes no allowance for inflation. Consequently, the United States capital gains tax is much harsher than the Australian capital gains tax in its present form. For instance, if one had an investment in the United States and it appreciated at, say, 8 per cent a year for five years and inflation were running at 8 per cent one would have a capital gains tax on one's investment gain of 34 per cent over that five-year period. In Australia one would pay no tax at all, because if the inflation rate were running at 8 per cent, it would neutralise the 8 per cent capital appreciation. So there is no doubt that the Australian capital gains tax is very mild indeed by world standards. If the Liberal Party were responsible at all, it would acknowledge that fundamental fact.

I come to the fourth difference between the American tax system and ours. I make these comparisons because it is very interesting that the United States had a tax reform package running at almost identically the same time as Australia's tax reform package was introduced, so it is very relevant to compare the two tax systems. The fifth difference is that in the United States a number of company tax concessions have been abolished, including the investment allowance and accelerated depreciation. The net effect of these abolitions of allowances in company tax has been to increase company tax by a massive $194 billion over five years. Although the nominal rate of tax in the United States has fallen from 46 to 34 per cent, the actual tax paid by companies will increase by 25 per cent. This is a factor that has to be taken into account.

The sixth essential difference between our tax system and that of the United States is that married couples in the United States of America file a joint tax return. If they earn, say, $35,000 each, they are taxed jointly on their combined

income of $70,000. The major difference between our system and that of the United States is this: In addition to the United States levying a sales tax, the majority of States also levy income tax, with top rates of 10 per cent. These taxes are in addition to the Federal tax.

So what is the net effect of the mixes in the United States and the mixes in Australia? Let us look at the facts. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures, in 1984 total taxation represented 31 per cent of gross domestic product in Australia compared with 29 per cent of gross domestic product in the United States. The figures would not be substantially different today because, although there have been changes, the tax packages in both the United States and Australia are revenue neutral. So it is fair to say that overall, on the basis of gross domestic product, Australians are taxed at a rate 2 per cent higher than people in the United States. However, I would have thought that there was not a great deal of difference.

The Opposition persists with its policy of wanting its cake and eating it too. It continually draws attention to the top marginal rate of income tax in the United States of 33 per cent. Members of the Opposition say: `Whacko, let us do that in Australia as well'. They want the goodies without the nasties. I think they have adopted an irresponsible attitude in putting this argument before the public. The figures have to be looked at carefully.
The Australian Democrats have been in the hot seat right through the debate on this tax package.

TALK.START.PARA: —You poor old things.

—Nothing motivates Australians more than the hip pocket nerve, Senator Messner. It was a very easy and, I might say again, irresponsible attitude for the Opposition to adopt when it said: `We will just flat-footedly oppose the whole tax package'. Tax reform is necessary in this country. The Opposition has stood flat-footed and opposed the package without trying to draw attention to or come up with reforms in any shape or form. What is more, the Opposition has said that if it forms a government it will eliminate most of the package without telling us what it would put in its place. That is an irresponsible attitude to take. The Democrats have been put into the position of having to decide whether to join the Opposition in opposing the whole tax package which, without any doubt at all, would have precipitated a double dissolution earlier this year on the question of tax cuts, at a time when the Opposition would not have had any hope at all of winning an election. The opinion polls made that abundantly clear to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has played politics right throughout this whole tax package, as Senator Messner's secret memo indicated. For instance, it looked as though the capital gains tax legislation was going to be defeated and that the Government would have been given an excuse to call a double dissolution. Senator Messner said, in writing: `Well, we will get a few Liberals to cross the floor so that the capital gains tax in fact does pass'. If that is not playing politics, I do not know what is. Senator Messner's memo is in writing and he has not yet denied that he wrote it. It is in black and white, on the records and in Hansard.

The reforms which have received so much publicity and for which the Government has taken so much credit are not the reforms that the Democrats would have liked to have seen. They are not the reforms the Government claims they are. However, we support this legislation. We have supported the tax package with the very important amendments that have been negotiated by the Democrats because they in fact lessen the tax paid by ordinary taxpayers and restores some sort of incentive by dropping the top marginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent.

The debate on this group of tax Bills has raised again the question of the fringe benefits tax. I want to comment on that tax. The Government in fact has conceded that there have to be changes to the mechanism by which the fringe benefits tax is applied. As I said before, and say again: Bravo, we told the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at the time we were negotiating the fringe benefits tax package with him that that had to happen. If we had had some support from the Liberal Party the fringe benefits tax would now be in a form which would be understandable to all Australians and which would be responsible. But no, the Liberals were going to oppose it flat-footed. The Liberal Party has not yet told us what sort of fringe benefits tax it is going to introduce. It has left it to the seven Democrats to do all the negotiating on the whole of this tax package.

We tried very hard to get the Treasurer to agree to a flat tax on motor cars but he would not allow that at the time. He would not change the major thrust of his legislation and after having got a $200m concession, a concession that Senator Button tried three times to get in Cabinet but was rolled on it three times, we felt there was a limit as to how far seven Democrats could or should push a government.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you caved in.

—I am giving the Opposition the facts of life. It does not like to hear them. It has never liked to hear them. The Government has finally conceded that it must simplify the fringe benefits tax. I want to put four simple reforms forward, which I hope the Government will think about and which will make the whole fringe benefits tax workable. The first is to scrap the car log book.

SPEECH.PARA: I have told honourable senators that we tried to get the Government to scrap the log book. We put to the Treasurer that there should be a flat rate of tax on motor cars. If we had had some support from Senator Messner, who sits there and laughs about this now, the fringe benefits tax would not be in the mess it is in today. I repeat, we could scrap the log book quite simply. It is common practice for the Commissioner of Taxation to have a fixed formula for different occupations. For instance, the Commissioner could allow a plumber to claim 70 per cent of his car expenses. The Tax Commissioner may also lay down a formula which would allow an accountant to claim 50 per cent of his car expenses as a deduction. This is common practice and the Taxation Office does it right now. The Democrats can see no reason why formulas could not be laid down for different occupations, allowing interest and depreciation as a business expense. There is no reason why the Tax Office could not come up with a formula to apply to different types of businesses and business operations. This would greatly ease the administrative burden of the car tax and it would not affect revenue one iota.

Secondly, to ensure that petty benefits, such as the provision of parking and other small payments in kind, are not hit, we believe there should be a threshold of $1,000 a year, and those receiving less than this amount in fringe benefits would not be taxed. At present the employer has only two choices with fringe benefits. He has either to pay or cash out the benefit. I believe this third option should be considered: The employer could declare the benefit on the employee's group certificate to ensure that the tax becomes the employee's responsibility. Deductions could be made from the weekly wage to cover any tax payable. In that way a very simple mechanism would allow the benefit to the employee to be taxed in the hands of the employee which, of course, in equity is where it should have always been taxed.

The fourth reform we suggest is that the Taxation Office should be empowered to issue exemptions to groups which feel that they would be adversely affected by the fringe benefits tax. These would be organisations such as non-profit groups, say, the National Trust and the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The RSPCA is very concerned that it is going to be taxed under the fringe benefits legislation and that will cause it enormous hardship and result in a great diminution of its services to animals in this country. If the Government were to take these four simple options, much of the heat over the FBT would be dissipated. These are practical, simple and straightforward suggestions.

TALK.START.PARA: —By gee, what a backoff! I have never heard anything like it. It's a disgrace.

—Senator Walters refuses to concede that at least the Democrats had the moral fortitude to do something about a tax package. The Opposition has done nothing, has said that it opposes everything, and has not come up with one practical suggestion that I have heard of in this place in the last 18 months. Is it because the Opposition does not have any ideas, any brain power or is it because members of the Opposition cannot agree amongst themselves? Whatever the reason, the Liberal and National parties have been completely irresponsible over the whole tax package legislation. On that the record stands stark and clear. On behalf of the Democrats, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out paragraph (a) of the words proposed to be added, insert the following paragraph:
`(a) the Government should be condemned for-
(i) not indexing personal income tax rates, which has allowed inflationary factors virtually to neutralise the Government's tax cuts, and
(ii) very minor reductions in the marginal rate of tax at the level of the average income earner;'

The one bright spot about the whole tax package is that the Government is not quite intransigent. It is a very good sign that it has been prepared to admit that changes are necessary to the fringe benefits tax, and that it is calling for submissions to see ways and means of simplifying such a tax. I hope that the Government will take note of the Democrats' suggestions in this area. If it can come up with a formula that simplifies the fringe benefits tax, if it is prepared to face up to the indexing of personal income tax, we will have a tax reform package that will put this country well ahead. It is the first time any government has been prepared to face up to the tax issue in 40 years. No government has been prepared to grasp the nettle in all that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has made a botch of it.

—It has not made a botch of it at all. If I may use the honourable senator's words, it has made a botch of the fringe benefits tax in its application. That a fringe benefits tax was required is beyond doubt. One just has to look at the amount of revenue that has been forgone through tax rorts in the fringe benefits area. As an employer myself I can vouch for the fact that enormous amounts of revenue have been forgone through the rorts in the fringe benefits area. They had to be clamped down on. The fact that the Government did it in a ham-fisted way is a pity, but there is, at least to us, some glimmer of hope in the Government more or less admitting the error of its ways. If it can now come up with a fringe benefits tax which is workable, with a mild capital gains tax and with other reforms in the whole tax package, Australia will be set on a course that should be sound for many years ahead, at least through to the end of this century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most predictable aspects of the constant struggle for the hearts and minds of the electorate is the enthusiasm of governments to massage that most delicate anatomical portion of the body politic, the hip pocket nerve. The most popular snake oil remedy is undoubtedly tax cuts. Like most public policy questions there are two schools of thought: One sees tax relief as a tangible short term gesture for which the voters at the next election will be duly grateful; the other sees significant reductions in personal income tax as a macro-economic tool to restore incentive, lower labour costs, raise disposable income, and boost aggregate demand. Unfortunately, this legislation is definitely a product of the former school-fiddling at the margin; at best, too little too late; and, at worst, a feeble and cynical sleight of hand trick. This shabby act of legerdemain must be exposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Even after the 1 December tax cuts and taking into account the Medicare levy, the dependent spouse rebate, family allowance and the effects of inflation, families with a single breadwinner and two dependent children will still be $23.50 a week worse off than they were at the last election, in 1984. Taxpayers on average weekly earnings would need an extra $8 a week to be brought back to the March 1983 average tax rates. Over the last three years, the excise on a litre of petrol has risen from 6.1c to 19.7c. That is an additional cost of $6 a week in petrol for the average family. Even after both stages of the tax cuts are in place-after 1 December 1986 and 1 July 1987-both marginal and average income tax rates for taxpayers on average weekly earnings will be greater than they were in March 1983-a watershed date, one might think, in retrospect. Once the new rates are in place, a taxpayer on average weekly earnings will face a higher marginal tax rate and a higher average tax rate than he faced at the end of the Fraser Government's term in office.

In March 1983 the marginal tax rate was 30c in the dollar. It is now 46c in the dollar. Even with these very feeble changes, by July 1987 the marginal tax rate will be 40c in the dollar. In terms of average tax rates, in March 1983 the rate was 22.9c in the dollar; it is now 46c and by July 1987 it will be 24.5c. Again, the average taxpayer will need a cut of $8 a week just to stay level. These increases in personal income tax rates do not include such iniquities as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the abolition of negative gearing and the taking away of concessional expenditure rebates, as well as the numerous increases in indirect tax, including the increase in the petrol excise.

Despite the assurances of the trilogy, tax receipts have risen from 25 per cent of gross domestic product in 1984-85 to 25.2 per cent in 1985-86. They will rise again, to 25.5 per cent, in 1986-87. The Government expects to raise $1,400m in tax as a result of that breach of commitment-one might call it the wages of sin. The world's second worst Treasurer is now the world's greatest tax charlatan. Even Australian Council of Trade Unions Vice-President MacBean has cast doubts on whether tax cuts will help those with an income below $28,000. That is hardly the sort of approach one might have expected from a Labor government. It will certainly be of no benefit to the masses. By July 1987 about two million additional taxpayers will have moved out of the new 29c in the dollar tax bracket and into the 40c bracket, which will mean that 50 per cent of all taxpayers will be in the top marginal rate bracket.

This is the insidious bracket creep which enables governments to go on spending more and more and make apparent but illusory tax cuts. The Government's share of the national cake has risen from 31.6 per cent in 1972 to be now around 45 per cent. In 1984-85 the total number of taxpayers grew by less than 4 per cent, but the number in the top bracket grew by more than 33 per cent and the number in the next bracket by more than 32 per cent. With no adjustment, more and more Australians will be forced into higher and higher tax rate levels and will be faced with progressively savage tax bites which will be compounded by our-very impressive in terms of numerical order of magnitude-inflation rate which, as we all know, is well above the average for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It is a factor of four times greater than rates prevailing in the United States and Japan.

These wimpish, anodyne tax cuts will do nothing to correct the fundamental distortions of our personal income tax structure, with its massive reliance on personal income tax and all the implications for disincentive effects. The Liberals will be moving fundamentally to correct that position.

I now want to consider the international situation. The proportion that personal income tax, as a percentage of total tax revenue, provides in Australia is 45 per cent. One can compare that with figures of 39 per cent in the United States, 24 per cent in Japan, 27 per cent in West Germany, 33 per cent in Canada and 35 per cent in the United Kingdom. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average is 32 per cent. So the Australian figure is 40 per cent higher. Our personal income tax revenue as a percentage of total tax revenue is the fourth highest in the Western world. In terms of percentage of gross earnings for families with two children, we come in sixth, or, if one takes out the Scandinavian countries, we are third on the list. Total tax revenue from individuals in this financial year will be $32.7 billion. Total tax revenue will be $58.3 billion or 55 per cent. Currently the highest personal income tax percentage of total tax revenue occurs in New Zealand, but New Zealand has taken corrective action. It has moved away from an excessive reliance on personal income tax. It has had the courage to introduce what we would describe as a broad-based consumption tax. In New Zealand it is called a goods and services tax. It involves a 10 per cent tax on consumption. New Zealand at least has learned the error of its ways. The average tax rate in New Zealand will be 21 per cent, whereas in Australia it will be 25 per cent. In New Zealand the marginal tax rate on average weekly earnings will be 30 per cent. In Australia it will be 46 per cent.

If we look at the 1984 OECD figures on consumption tax as a percentage of gross domestic product, again we find that Australia derives only 8.7 per cent of its revenue from consumption tax. In Japan the figure is 3.55 per cent and in the United States, 4.58 per cent. The European Economic Community average is 12.25 per cent. The Australian figure is therefore 40 per cent lower. General consumption as a percentage of GDP in Australia is 2.37 per cent, which is less than half the OECD average. Australia has the lowest figure of all OECD countries. Instead of the Government biting the bullet on option C, as we recommended, and moving towards a broad-based consumption tax, we now have such iniquities as the substantiation maze, with all the receipt books, log books and bits of paper that will make Australian taxpayers so unproductive and so infuriated in the run-up to the next election. We are doing our very best to create a nation of paper shufflers, amongst whom the rewards will be greatest for those who are prepared to engage in what is essentially tax fiddling. There is an absolute disincentive effect on any productive activity. The fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are punishment for those who might have been brave enough but who now would be foolish to take entrepreneurial risks. In delivering the 15th annual Wilfred Fullagar memorial lecture at Monash University recently, a noted tax expert warned of the inevitable collapse of the income tax system and predicted that `the future belongs to consumption taxation'. Professor Ross Parsons was a member of the 1975 Asprey Taxation Review Committee and is a founding governor of the Australian Tax Research Foundation. These are his words:

There is no relief for us save for the coming of the ultimate state envisaged by the Asprey Committee, when the income tax has been abolished in favour of what can be a simple tax on goods and services.

But this Government is not interested in real tax reform. In the corporate tax area, there will be a movement upwards from 46c to 49c in the dollar. The effect of that will be that only two countries in the Western world will have higher rates of corporate taxation on distributed dividends than Australia-France and Ireland. Their rate will be 50c. So one could say that we are right at the top of the table when it comes to corporate tax rates.

One could say that there are pressures and reforms sweeping the world and one would have thought that these initiatives would have a great deal to offer Australia. But tragically that is not the case. Mr Hawke, as recently as 10 October this year-he was slightly provoked by John Howard suggesting that there may well be some real merit in recent United States tax reform initiatives-said:

The sweeping reforms of the Australian tax system brought in by my Government will produce a fairer and more efficient tax system. There is no need for this Australian Government to look to the American reforms as a model for Australia.

That almost verges on the tragic. I noted with interest that Senator Siddons dismissed the United States position by simply pointing to some of those differences which he says make the comparison irrelevant. But I remind the Senate that, even with the massive simplification and collapsing of the marginal rate structure, Americans will still be able to deduct housing mortgage interest rates; so middle class America will still have a sizable deductibility buffer to reduce the real burden of given nominal tax rates. Thus the effective real burden of high marginal tax rates will be a lot higher on middle income earners in Australia than in comparable countries overseas.

It is quite clear that in Australia we have an inward looking approach, a pathetic myopia. Even in today's Age Max Walsh talked about the United States positivists. To paraphrase the Managing Director of Elders IXL, Mr John Elliott, what Max Walsh might have said is that in America the optimists run the country while in Australia it is the pessimists. A couple of leading tax experts in this country have warned that the Australian tax cuts are too small. That even seems to be the position of the Australian Democrats, who are proposing an amendment to the effect that the Government should be condemned for its very minor reductions in the marginal rate of tax at the level of the average income earners. Even the Democrats seem to have a glimmer of understanding of the real situation.

There are experts in this country who have made it very clear that the Australian tax cuts are derisory and are too small to avert the risk of Australian business being undercut by United States competitors. Professor Michael Porter, who has been running the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University for some years, has recently been commissioned to prepare a national priorities project which will deal with real tax reform proposals, hopefully by early next year. Professor Porter has said--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not going to rely on him, surely.

—I would hope that there is scope for some sanity in the debate and that what will come out of the national priorities project is a substantial move towards broadening the indirect taxation base and a substantial lowering of the direct tax base. Professor Porter says that it is feasible for Australia to adopt United States type reforms involving adjusting income and corporate tax rates and broadening the indirect taxation base. I do not have any doubt that Australian companies would be prepared to wear the same increase as has been introduced in America if they could be sure that all the other factors in the equations would be beneficial. But at the moment they are simply of the view, as reported in this morning's paper in an address to a management survey, that Australia is about the last place in the world where corporate entrepreneurs would want to invest.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Porter says that the starting point is the threshold below which Australians are not charged income tax. That threshold currently stands at around $5,000 and below that figure there is something of the order of $40 billion a year in untaxed income. It is quite feasible to have a compensatory facility to look after those who are genuinely disadvantaged by the application of a tax rate below the current threshold level.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be raised, not lowered.

—If it is simply raised, the tax base is being narrowed, which I think is the last thing that is necessary at present. Presumably one would then have fewer and fewer taxpayers being asked and expected to pay more and more tax, but in reality doing the opposite. One would drive productive activity underground, ensure that the black economy is the only growth industry and ensure that most people are able, as they always have been, to avoid paying the higher rates of income tax. Professor Porter has said that the United States package provides a tax exempt income threshold of some $2,000 for single people and $5,000 for married couples, which he describes as minuscule on the basis of much higher average incomes in the United States when compared with the levels at which the top rates were introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that, if the original purpose of top marginal tax rates was somehow to ensure that those at the top of the tree were paying a much larger slice, any such rationale has long since disappeared. The most illuminating example I can think of is the fact that 25 years ago Australians would have had to earn $170,000, in current dollars, to qualify for today's top marginal rate of 60 per cent. Put another way, something like 15 years ago one would have had to earn about 11 1/2 times average weekly earnings, whereas today it is about 1 1/2 times. The very last people who should be paying the top marginal rate of tax are those on or about average weekly earnings. Yet we find that once these magnificent reforms are in place, more than 50 per cent of total taxpayers will be paying the top marginal rate.

If one compares the two systems it is clear, in the words of Dr Ian Spry, who is another noted taxation expert in this country, that the United States operates a much broader system than Australia, with rates set at lower levels, and that the introduction of a similar system here would mean cutting the rate on a narrower range of taxable items such as petrol but imposing a lesser rate of tax on a much wider range of consumption goods.

As Professor Porter has repeatedly pointed out, the threshold is the problem. I therefore want to examine the effect of the threshold for a moment. The problem with the tax free threshold is that there are very many income earners or recipients in this country paying no tax at all. We have already seen that something of the order of $40 billion is tax free below that level. It is clear, therefore, that unless some move is made to garner those funds, even at modest rates, the capacity for introducing lower marginal rates, certainly at the higher end, is very much constrained. If one abolished the tax threshold altogether, for example, at a rate of 20 per cent, the amount yielded would be an extra $6.6 billion, which would easily pay for the overdue reduction in the current marginal rates. Even with a compromise tax free threshold of $1,000, a 20 per cent tax rate would raise $5.3 billion or more. The raising of the tax threshold from $4,595 to $5,100, as we have in this legislation, runs counter to the current move to find revenue sources to allow for a reduction in high marginal tax rates. Income tax, including company tax and FBT, will actually increase from 67.5 per cent to 69.1 per cent of total tax revenue. This reflects strong increases in direct taxation stemming from the operation of bracket creep.

Australia is once more going in the opposite direction to the rest of the world and the opposite direction to the imperatives of economic logic, and it will reap its ultimate reward. The effect of the Budget, as we have all seen in the assessments of commentators, is that by a very devious mirrors and beads trick the Treasurer was able to achieve a Budget deficit outcome of $3.5 billion. But he did not do that in the manner most thought he would do it-by the reduction of real expenditure. He did it by imposing a whole range of new taxes which will raise something of the order of $1.4 billion, by currency speculation by the Reserve Bank of Australia, which had classic windfall one-off profits of $600 billion, and something of the same order by the miserable deferral of welfare increases until 1 December.

The Liberal Party, as I said, will go in the opposite direction. We believe in a lower, simpler and more durable tax regime. We will rationalise and broaden existing indirect taxation arrangements. We will reduce higher marginal rates of personal income tax and we will provide a bias in personal income tax in favour of families. It is quite clear from the shallow and superficial proposals contained in the Bills before us that Australians will not be any better off. This legislation is another feeble gesture in the direction of the next Federal election and will be forgotten long before then. The Government will then be faced with explaining why more and more people are paying more and more tax.

I turn now to the Medicare Levy Bill. This is a fundamental example of the Government's ill-considered approach to revenue raising. One would have thought that the levy would be designed actually to assist the Government in containing and affording the increases in health costs in this country. But the fact is that, firstly, it is a very deliberate breach of an election promise. Perhaps we should not be surprised at that. One does not charge governments with false and misleading advertising; one simply assumes that leaders of political parties can be relied upon to honour at least the majority of their election promises unless there is a very good reason to the contrary. But this Bill involves a cold, cynical and deliberate action of breaking a promise not to increase the Medicare levy. It is now an empty charade to pretend that the levy is related to health costs. In many ways this Bill is a measure of the desperation of this Government and its absolutely critical need to raise revenue by whatever means for general budgetary purposes. There is no defined link between the levy and health costs; it is just a tax by another name.

In 1985-86 total health costs were $3,634m, which consisted of $2,589m for medical benefits and $1,045m for public hospital costs. Revenue from the levy was $1,335m, which is about 35 per cent of total health costs. In the current Budget the estimated expenditure will be $3,939m-which is an increase of less than 10 per cent-yet the levy is to be increased by 25 per cent. The reason for this must be patently obvious: The Government long ago gave up the battle to control the explosion of health care costs. It must now stand condemned for its abject and total failure at cost containment policies. There has been a belated effort to tackle some of the massive overservicing and excessive charges in areas such as radiology and pathology but by and large as long as we retain a health care funding program which does not require consumers to take any real interest in or scrutiny of the manner and level of the charging we will get what we deserve-increasing health costs for no real or apparent increase in health.

The real vice is the absolute lack of any incentive for patient scrutiny or involvement. Consumers can afford to remain ignorant and apathetic because they know that the tab is being picked up by the Government. They cannot labour under the illusion that it is a free bite; they know full well that it is not, as should the Government. Cutbacks in government funding for the health sector inevitably will have to follow unless costs are contained. The concept of the levy is fundamentally flawed. Unless and until it is related to some form of user pays principle we will simply see health costs running much further ahead of government than the Government might hope to catch up with any increase in the levy. Good health might be a priceless asset in this community; health costs certainly are not. The greatest beneficiaries of the current arrangements are the health providers. The users of the most expensive and sophisticated biotechnology are simply encouraged by the system to provide for average Australians the very best of hospital and medical care irrespective of the consequences. There is no incentive to use sparingly when there is no real cost burden applicable or, in economists' terms, there is no incentive for maximising behaviour.

It is possible that one day the Government will move towards such vehicles as health management organisations. It might require Australians to take out cover for only catastrophic health costs. But there is no sign of it in this Bill. It is clear that unless competition amongst providers is introduced we will simply encourage consumers to go on in an undisciplined use of services. Consumers will be encouraged to demand the best. No-one will care particularly what it costs, except the Government when it is thrown out at the next election.

I shall briefly address some of the comments of Senator Maguire, if they are meant to be representative of the Government's defence on these Bills. He talked about horrifying inflationary consequences. It is a pretty shabby and specious approach to say that indirect taxes will have any sort of permanent inflationary effect. They may well have a one-off effect and certainly would have that effect with full wage indexation. Now that it, mercifully, has been abandoned there is no necessary reason why there should be any significant increase in inflation. After all, if we were trading a broadening of the income tax base for substantial tax cuts, the average weekly wage earner would have a higher level of disposable income so as not to need any adjustment to his wages. It is claimed that these cuts will restore progressivity to the tax system. I think that myth disappeared long ago. It is clear that once there are punitive rates of marginal tax inventive Australians-perhaps inventive citizens of the world-will find ways and means of avoiding payment of such rates. The suggestion of the redistribution of the tax burden to lower and middle income wage earners is simply jargon and rhetoric. To demolish that suggestion one can do no better than to refer to the words of John MacBean, who said one has to earn more than $28,000 a year to get any benefit from even these miserable marginal rate reductions.

In essence, the legislation is backward looking. The Government's approach is an obsession with the historic environment. It is really not much comfort. The Government will not gain any credibility by pointing to what might have happened in bygone years and suggesting that for some reason or another other governments have not been able to bite the tax bullet. Australia's predicament is greater than it has ever been before and there is no reason why genuine and substantial changes in the income tax structure cannot be introduced. The Government has not done this. Where I come from this is called gutlessness. Perhaps in this place it should be called a lack of intestinal fortitude. Unless this Government is prepared to adopt a tax regime that restores incentive and rewards those who are prepared to go out and strive, it will be left with more and more taxpayers being brought into the top marginal tax rate. The Government will therefore attract all the odium it deserves and will get the deserved result at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is without doubt a general recognition in Australia that there is a tremendous crisis in our economy. Yet the Government's answer to that is the introduction of a whole new spate of taxes. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that we are heading toward becoming a banana republic. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) told us that our economic crisis is so great that it is similar to the crisis we faced when we were at war. We all remember the Treasurer's banana republic statements and his statement that the Australian economy had fallen into a hole and that we cannot go on living beyond our means as we had done for some time. The Prime Minister said that we all have to pull in our belts, that the situation is so bad Australians have to pull together to get out of this crisis and that he alone cannot do it. The Opposition has been telling the Government for the last couple of years that this would occur, that its policies and its economic management of this country were not the way to go. Apart from the Opposition, many other people had been saying it, too. Indeed, Statement No. 2 of Budget Paper No. 1 of August 1985, at page 73, stated that a marked deterioration in the terms of trade was expected. What did the Treasurer say in September 1985? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if we were providing these policy settings and outcomes in Western Europe, they'd be lighting candles to us in cathedrals.

What is wrong with the man? The Treasury tells him what to expect, and he tells the Australian people that if he provided these policy settings and outcomes in Western Europe, people would be lighting candles to him in the cathedrals. He was out to deceive the Australian population, and that is unforgivable in a Treasurer. In November, a month or two later, he said:

Notwithstanding the balance of payments figures from the early part of the financial year, the Government continues to expect a substantial decline on the current account deficit over the course of 1985-86 and subsequently.

So despite Treasury warnings and Opposition warnings, despite the fact that the Opposition told the Treasurer daily that he was wrong, the Treasurer said that he expected a decline in the current account deficit. He would not take any notice of the Treasury or the Opposition. But what occurred? In April there was a current account deficit for the quarter of $3.5 billion. In particular, the figure for the month of April stunned the Treasurer and had him running for cover. We did not hear from him for 24 hours. He would not answer any media request for interviews. He just ran for cover and then came out with his banana republic statement. Yet the picture had been painted for many months. The picture had been painted over a period of years by the Opposition. We were all told by every economist that it would happen. We knew that it was occurring. But the Treasurer, like Nelson, turned a blind eye to what was happening and misled the population in an irresponsible manner. But I do not refer only to the Treasurer. In January this year the Prime Minister said:
. . . I guess the range of options-
that is, on the appropriate value of the dollar-
is 72 to 75 cents.

We all know what happened when the bottom dropped out of the dollar. The latest announcement of the balance of trade figures is horrific. The figures for the first quarter of the new financial year, for 1986-87, are the worst quarterly figures in Australia's history. The figure increased by 19 per cent when compared to the figure for the same quarter last year. Indeed, the current account deficit figure issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics was $4,263m, which is an increase of $670m or 19 per cent on the deficit recorded in the three months ending September 1985. It is a record. What did the Prime Minister say? He said he was reasonably satisfied with the latest balance of payment figures. In a newspaper article he is reported as saying:
The deficit result was within the range of market expectations and reflects the impact of the June and July devaluations of 10 to 11 per cent.

He was happy with it. He said that the deficit result was within the range of market expectations. So if the expectation of the market is that we are going broke and that the whole country is in a dreadful mess, and if, indeed, that comes about, the Prime Minister just says: `That is all right. I am reasonably happy with it. It is in the range of market expectations'. What an incredible statement by the Prime Minister. Of course, not everybody agrees with him. John Spalvins, the Managing Director of the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd, said, although he did not name Mr Hawke, that he was quite surprised at how people had reacted to the current account deficit. He said:
$1.45 billion sounds like a lot of money to me and I believe it is a lot of money.

But perhaps we're getting blase. The financial markets and population at large seem to have accepted it. I'm personally quite concerned about it and I believe that we cannot continue spending something that we haven't got, and it has got to be corrected.

Yet the Prime Minister passes it off by saying that he is reasonably happy about it. But let us look at what has happened since he made the statement that he thought the dollar had reached its proper level at about US72c. We all remember when the Australian dollar was worth 127.6 Japanese yen. That was on 15 April this year. It then started its slide in earnest. It went down to 95 yen at one stage. Everyone said it could not go below 100 yen, but it is still below 100 yen. I guess the Prime Minister is still quite happy, because that would reflect market expectations. The Australian dollar, as we all know, is called the Australian peso. This wonderful Treasurer, as was said the other day, only two years ago was called the financial Minister of the year. Now he has only narrowly been beaten for the wooden spoon award for the man who had done the most harm to any economy. He was only beaten for the wooden spoon award by the Finance Minister for Egypt. That is the level we have reached under this Government. This country is facing a crisis of world stature.

Apart from our dollar reaching the peso level, what else has happened? The 1986 Budget which was brought down by this Government was not a Budget of great cuts; it was a Budget of great taxes. There have been a few deferments of pensions for those who are least able to cope in the community. But it was a Budget of taxes, not a Budget of government cuts. Let us look at what the Prime Minister had promised us. The Prime Minister said:
We will undertake to be able to meet our objectives-
of the trilogy-
by ensuring restraints on the growth of expenditure; that is government expenditure will be beneath the rate of growth in the economy.

What happened in this Budget? Government expenditure went up by $4.8 billion; and even if one takes inflation into account, it has still gone up. The Prime Minister said in a speech to the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce:
I give you, a critically important audience, the categorical assurance that there will be no overall increase in the tax burden next year or through our next term of office.

What a promise to be broken! Nothing but tax cuts have been mentioned, yet in the Budget we have had nothing but increases in taxes. The Medicare levy will be increased, and surely government members do not consider that that is not a tax. We have a fringe benefits tax, a capital gains tax, the quarterly payment of provisional tax is being brought in, and we have the quarantining of interest rates on housing units. We have had the lot. Everything imposed will be an extra burden on the business community. All that these taxes have succeeded in doing is getting rid of small business incentives. All they have succeeded in doing is saying to small business: `The climate is becoming impossible for you to expand. You cannot expect to make a dollar, because if you do it will be taken away from you by the Government in the form of taxes'. Yet the Government and the unions are abusing the business world for not expanding. They are saying: `You cannot expect us to take less wages unless you expand', and so the vicious circle goes on. Unions are not just asking for investment and expansion; they are demanding as a quid pro quo that investment and expansion take place.

Let us look at what has happened to the fringe benefits tax. Today we heard from Senator Siddons the most incredible speech that I have ever heard in this Parliament. He said that there is a limit to which seven Democrats can go to push the Government. That is the excuse he gave for not putting up amendments to the fringe benefits tax that would have overcome those unintended consequences that the Government and Mr Hawke are now facing. Immediately after the fringe benefits tax was introduced and on every day since in this Parliament the Opposition has brought more anomalies and more unintended consequences to the attention of the Government and the Democrats. We had letters in the most arrogant terms from Mr Keating stating that the tax would not be altered, that the free accommodation of people who were in private homes looking after disabled people had to be included in the fringe benefits tax for equity's sake. He would not back off. There was no unexpected consequences from which the Government would back off. Mr Keating said that the tax would continue. Now Mr Hawke has backed off and has acknowledged that there are unintended consequences. On Sunday Senator Walsh said that these consequences were not his fault, that he is not a draftsman, and that it was all the fault of the bureaucracy. He did not know that unintended consequences would occur. He relied on the draftsmen not to include them in the legislation. We have not been able to get an answer as to what directions were given to the draftsmen. Senator Walsh will not answer our questions. I would dearly love to know what directions the Government gave to the draftsmen, because I believe that it intended to pick up every single bit of money it possibly could, despite earlier promises from the Prime Minister when he said the following to the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce:
. . . there will be no overall increase in the tax burden . . .

The Government intended to pick up every single cent it could, and the Treasurer had no intention of backing off. Mr Hawke has assured us that there will be substantive changes-`changes in substance' he said. But Mr Keating has said that there will not be changes in substance; there will be only administrative changes. Senator Walsh, in his true style, ducks for cover and blames the bureaucrats. Mr Hawke is now backing off and saying: `We will extend the date for the payment of the fringe benefits tax, seeing that we will be reviewing it. We realise that 28 October-only eight or nine days left-will not be the date on which we will be able to enforce payment. We will now reset that date'. What date do honourable senators think he chose? He chose the eleventh of the eleventh 1986. That is a pretty emotive day for the Australian Labor Party, and I can assure it that it is just as emotive to change the date on which the fringe benefits tax is payable to that date, as 11 November 1975 ever was.

Yesterday Senator Cook told us that we were all being subversive in criticising the economy, that we should not be criticising the Government on the way its economic policy has been going, that this was all undermining the country, and that we should all keep quiet and let ourselves go down the plug hole silently. He will never be able to stop the Opposition from bringing to the Australian people the problems they are facing, even if Mr Keating is willing to hide the facts, and indeed insists upon hiding them, until they eventually speak for themselves. The Treasurer has reached the stage at which he cannot any longer be trusted by overseas nations. Europe is not burning candles for him. Yesterday we were told that executives of Moody's Investor Services Inc. are furious at the premature leak of its controversial assessment of the Australian political climate. A telex from an Australian Associated Press correspondent states:
They were shocked today to learn that the Treasurer, Paul Keating, read a copy of their report in Parliament . . .
The Moody's spokesman stressed that the political analysis of Australia is not part of last month's credit review.
He said it is a separate document, still in its draft stages.

That organisation was stupid enough to give the Treasurer a copy of its draft. It thought that it could trust him when he came home. But because he was smarting from the fact that he was copping a bit of flak over just missing out on being given the wooden spoon as the Treasurer who had done the worst in terms of economic management, he leaked this international document. That is the sort of credibility that our Treasurer has on the international stage at the moment. He is someone who cannot be trusted to hold a confidential document which is only in draft form. He will leak such a document to his own advantage if he is smarting from being under attack.

How on earth can Australia compete? Let me now turn to another area. We are told by the Treasurer that there is no way that we can get the prices we want for our goods on overseas markets, that other countries should be paying us more for our exports and that, until they do, we cannot compete. What a defeatist attitude. What we have to do is get out there and compete at the prices other countries will pay for our products. How are we going to do that if we cannot bring down our interest rates, inflation rates and increases in average weekly earnings to those of our competitors? Just let us compare those rates. Low interest rates are essential if business is to be able to expand and compete on the open market. The latest figures show that interest rates in Australia are 17.9 per cent; West Germany, 4.4 per cent; Japan, 4.7 per cent; the United States of America, 5.6 per cent; Canada, 8.4 per cent; and France, 7.1 per cent. How can our business compete with interest rates like that? It is not possible for it to do so. Mr Keating cannot say that people must pay us the price that we want so that we can keep living in the manner to which we have been accustomed. What we must do is compete at the price that other countries are prepared to pay.

Our inflation rate is 8.4 per cent; West Germany, 0.2 per cent; Japan, 0.5 per cent; the United States, 1.7 per cent; Canada, 3.7 per cent; and France, 2.3 per cent. Again, how can we possibly compete when we have inflation rates that are so much higher than those of our competitors? It just is not possible for us to do so. Average weekly earnings in Australia have risen by 6.5 per cent. The rise in West Germany has been 3.3 per cent-almost half of that of Australia. The rise in Japan was 2.2 per cent; the United States, 2.4 per cent; Canada, 2.6 per cent; and France, 4.8 per cent.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) is yawning his head off. I find this to be typical of the whole of the Labor Government's approach to this situation. As far as it is concerned, this matter is a big yawn. This typifies its whole attitude. The Prime Minister said that he was reasonably happy with our current deficit, that he was reasonably happy that it was within the market predictions. He said that he was reasonably happy, when the deficit is the worst on record. Senator Evans, in his usual style, sits back in his seat and yawns his head off when I am pointing out that we cannot possibly compete, that our businesses can no longer compete because of our high interest rates, inflation rates and level of average weekly earnings compared with those of other countries.

I would now like to point out something to the yawning senator and to the Australian Democrats. I suppose that the Democrats are less interested in this matter than even the Labor Party is because, while Senator Evans sits back in his seat yawning his head off, the Democrats are not even in the chamber for the debate. Senator Siddons said: `We did not ever really agree with the fringe benefits tax and the way in which it was all done but there is a limit to what seven Democrats can do to push the Government'. What absolute bunkum. They did not have to agree with the fringe benefits tax. They went along with the Government-they went along happily. They did not put amendments to the fringe benefits tax legislation. They were perfectly happy to support the Government. We have reached the stage where demonstrations are taking place all over the country against the tax; we have reached the stage where the rural community has said that it will not pay the tax; we have reached the stage where disabled persons are having to pay the fringe benefits tax on the free accommodation they give to people who are helping them. Now the Democrats say: `Well, we really did not ever believe that it was all right but there is a limit to what seven Democrats can do to push the Government'. That is disgraceful behaviour. It is time they woke up to what they are doing because they had the opportunity to join with us and knock back the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately a package of taxation measures-namely, the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Medicare Levy Bill 1986. The Opposition will not be opposing these Bills. However, we will be pointing out to the people of Australia three things: First, the Government's taxation policy, in particular its fringe benefits and capital gains taxes, is causing damage and confusion throughout the whole community; secondly, the Government's failure to deliver tax cuts on 1 September 1986, as promised in 1985, has caused additional hardships to families; and, thirdly, this Government is the highest taxing government in history with tax receipts estimated to reach 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are supposed to represent the goodies of the Government's 1985 taxation package, so appropriately called RATS for short-reform of the Australian tax system. However, to call these Bills and other parts of the taxation package a reform is a sham. As everyone knows, the tax package was a deal worked out by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) behind the back of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in a motel room on the other side of Lake Burley Griffin on the last night of the failed tax summit. It was, and remains, the failed tax package of a government that is obviously in decay. As I have said before, it is the tax package that the Treasurer himself did not want.

Let me remind honourable senators of the Treasurer's statement of 19 September last year. Of course these days he is now not the world's greatest Treasurer. I understand he is the second worst. According to the Euromoney magazine, the world's worst finance Minister is Mr Sultan Abu Ali of Egypt but `the men responsible for economic policy in Yugoslavia, Morocco, Australia, even Malaysia, were all strong contenders'. So there it is-the second best tax option from the world's second worst Treasurer. Last year the Treasurer told the people of Australia: `We have set policies for growth'. What happened? This year we have had three quarters of negative growth; record interest rates; rising inflation, particularly when compared with the rest of the world, including our trading partners; stagnating economic activity; a massive current account imbalance which, annualised, could reach figures as high as $17 billion this year; and continued high unemployment. So much for the policies of growth in the tax statement last September. The irony is that the Government's own tax and budgetary policies are to blame for the slide we have suffered. The fringe benefits tax is nothing short of a disaster. The capital gains tax is throwing up new anomalies by the minute and the new sales tax measures announced in the Budget will add to inflation and increase business costs. We will have yet more petrol price hikes which will hit families the hardest and there is the further slug for Medicare, the disaster to end all disasters. For all this the taxpayers of Australia are going to get a few lousy cents cut from their marginal tax rates.

These savings will soon be gobbled up by inflation and fiscal drag, such is the great reform of the taxation system delivered by what the Treasurer used to call this `can-do Government'. Last year we had the White Paper, the National Taxation Summit, the back down, the deal and the statement. We also had the Prime Minister's nine principles of tax reform, the so-called nine commandments. These were to be the basis upon which the Government was to deliver us our tax nirvana. Let us look at some of them. First, there is the principle that there must be no increase during the Australian Labor Party's term in office of the overall tax burden as measured by the share of gross domestic product taken by the Government in tax revenues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strike one.

—Yes, strike one. There is more to come. This was part of the notorious trilogy which we do not hear much about these days. What has actually happened? In the last two Budgets the Government has increased the percentage of tax collected as a proportion of gross domestic product. In 1986-87 the Government will collect $1.4 billion more in additional tax collections over the trilogy ceiling. Tax collections, as a proportion of gross domestic product, have gone up from 20 to 25.5 per cent in the last year-yet another broken promise by this Government. Let us look at the second Hawke principle of tax reform. Any tax reform must continue the process of providing cuts in personal income tax. The tax cuts in December this year and July next year will simply be giving back to people money that is rightfully theirs anyway.
