The cuts will be largely paid for by inflation-something which this Government knows all about- given that our inflation rate is several times higher than that of our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development partners, and approximately four times higher than, for instance, that of Japan and not by the bevy of anti-business taxes introduced by this Government. But the crucial point is that in spite of the Government's promised tax cuts people, particularly struggling single income families, will be worse off.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Hawke Government came to office in 1983 people on average weekly earnings were paying a marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar. After both lots of tax cuts for this year and next year those taxpayers will be forking out 40c in the dollar; an increase of a whopping 30 per cent. Similarly, with average rates of tax, both single income earners and families will be considerably worse off and unfortunately for the Government the people out there know that they are already worse off. It is a fact that since 1983 families on average weekly earnings are $23.50 a week worse off, and that figure includes the December tax cuts. For the Government to claim that it is delivering real tax savings to the taxpayer is just as fallacious as its claim that it is the tax nasties who are paying for the alleged cuts.

The taxation treatment of families in this country is a national disgrace. According to a recently released Catholic Social Welfare Committee report entitled `Give Families a Fair Go', in the last 10 years the amount of income tax imposed on a family with four children living on average weekly earnings has increased 435 per cent, while wages have increased only 135 per cent. The report states that the deteriorating economic position of Australian families is also clearly seen when one compares over time the disposable share of earnings enjoyed by families. In two years' time an average weekly earner with a dependent spouse and five children will have nearly nine percentage points less in disposable shares of earnings than an average earner, with the same number of dependants, had in 1977. In contrast, an average weekly earner with no dependants will have two percentage points less in disposable share of earnings. Families, particularly large ones, are simply being discriminated against under the present tax transfer system.

The crucial point is that most Australian taxpayers with dependants, especially single income families, will suffer a decline in real income by 1988, despite the Government's tax cuts contained in the Bills before the Senate. When the Treasurer was overseas trying to explain why he felt he had done a good job, one newspaper report stated that one of the reasons given was that he had effectively lowered the standard of living of people in Australia. So it ill becomes the Government to think there will be dancing in the streets on 1 December over the new marginal tax rates. Any tax cut, of course, is to be welcomed. But a tax cut partly paid for by new taxes simply is not going to be worn by the great majority of taxpayers. The cuts should give struggling families very little to cheer about. Of course the 14 new taxes imposed by the Government in its recent Budget are not the only imposts which make life so hard for income earners. As from a couple of days ago car users have been paying the Government an additional 14c a litre in petrol tax. Reports in todays newspapers would indicate that people are now looking at having to pay something like 70c for a litre of petrol in the not too distant future.

Let us go to the fourth of the Prime Minister's principles of tax reform. It is that any reform must simplify the system so that all Australians can understand it more easily. I will not repeat the unparliamentary language used by the Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Tom Burns, when describing the simplicity of the fringe benefits tax. I believe the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, is also, very understandably, having considerable problems with the complexity of the administrative requirements of this tax. We have had several hundred pages of new legislation, explanatory memoranda, purple booklets, surveys by the Australian Taxation Office, administrative rulings and the tax hotline, but still small business is furious and confused. The paperwork involved in complying with the fringe benefits tax has variously been described as a nightmare, as horrifying and so on. Now we have a multi- million dollar advertising campaign to sell the tax package to be paid for again, of course, by the good old taxpayer. I am intrigued as to what this selling program will do. Is the Government going to go out there and say: `This tax is going to hurt us more than it is going to hurt you'? I do not know how it is going to explain this ridiculous tax to the people. Claims that this tax is aimed only at the tall poppies are totally fraudulent.

Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister on duty today in the chamber, will appreciate that when the fringe benefits tax is applied about 90 per cent of the blue collar workers in the remote mining areas will be affected by it. His colleague Senator Walsh has no hesitation in saying: `Cash them out'. The benefits cannot be cashed out. While talking on the fringe benefits tax I would also like to refer to a Government inspired report of the Maritime Industry Development Committee. At a time when we are urging people to increase their exports and trying to do something about our balance of payments, it is stated that the likely additional cost of the fringe benefits tax to Australian flag vessels will annually amount to $65,000 per ship. Here we are again penalising that very sector of the economy we wish to stimulate. The report of the Committee states:
It is inconceivable that Fringe Benefits Tax should be applied to items essential that traditionally provided for all seafarers to perform their duties on board ship, e.g. victualling.

The fringe benefits tax will apply to Australian flag vessels. It will not apply to foreign vessels coming to Australia. How on earth does one cash out a benefit such as that? There are no restaurants at sea.

It is now over a year since the tax package was announced. In that time we have had a stagnant private investment, negative growth, and rising unemployment. What a record? The tax package has not done the job; in fact, it has done the reverse. The fringe benefits and capital gains taxes are a massive disincentive to business activity. The Government says that it wants more capital investment to turn around our massive current account deficit. It has not got a hope of achieving this goal while it bashes those groups who actually turn the economy around, or have the capacity to turn it around. Compliance with the new tax regime is costing business heavily. It is simply a waste of time and money. It will not provide genuine relief for taxpayers.

I briefly refer to the capital gains tax with particular reference to the effect it may or may not have on farm-in arrangements. Senator Evans might have some new clarification on this, but the point is that a normal farm-in arrangement works in such a way that a person with a mining tenement may seek out a third party to come in and take a share in the mining tenement by carrying out certain exploration works. Money does not change hands. The question was raised by the industry: Does that farm-in attract to the original tenement holder a capital gains tax? The Treasurer attempted to clarify this. He made a statement on 6 August which probably confused people more than ever. In that Press release to the mining companies he said, among other things, that there had been reports, based on legal opinion, that people would be liable to pay capital gains tax in the year of the farm-in agreement on the value of future capital expenditure to be undertaken by the person farming-in. He went on to say that this was not the true position. Then he truly and thoroughly confused everyone concerned when he said:

That market value (the up-front sales price) would depend largely on the balance of the expected future returns from associated mineral discoveries over the amount of the expenditure commitments required to realise those returns, and could be very low at the early exploration stage.

That statement raised enormous confusion. I know requests have been made to Senator Evans and others to get this clarified. I have no idea where it stands. The interpretation by the companies was such that this could mean a number of things. It could mean that there was a capital gains tax on the amount paid. It could mean that there would be a capital gains tax down the track when it was found out whether the person or company that farmed-in made a future return. There is an element there of retrospectivity. If the person who farmed-in did have an expected future return would it be expected that the original tenement holder would have to pay a much greater capital gains tax. The Treasurer went on further to say:
In an arm's length sale, where there is tension between the parties-
whatever that means-

involved in negotiating the up-front sales price of the part disposal, that sale price would, in the absence of other relevant information, be accepted as the relevant consideration for capital gains purposes.

That contradicts what he said at the beginning of his statement. No wonder there was a state of absolute and utter confusion among these people. While industry was being told that there probably would not be any form of a capital gains tax-although the subsequent comments by the Treasurer certainly added to the great confusion-one company got a ruling from the Australian Taxation Office that it would have to pay a capital gains tax. Where on earth does the industry sit? The industry is still signing agreements, but there is a proviso in those agreements to the effect that agreements are conditional on there being no capital gains tax.

The Prime Minister's final principle of reform is that any reform package must have widespread community support. What have we got? We have a veritable tax revolt on our hands as more and more people realise that they are being affected by the nasties, the Prime Minister's so-called unintended consequences, and the goodies will seem more like just compensation than real reform. These Bills are a cruel hoax on the people of Australia. The cuts in marginal rates prescribed by the Bills are illusory and the increase in the Medicare levy is a disgraceful broken promise. What is the Prime Minister's word worth anyway these days? The Bills do little to increase incentives to be productive since there have been no changes to the levels at which marginal rates cut in. These Bills deserve the support of the Senate only because without their passage the people who provide this Government with money to waste would be even worse off than they are now. We need to create an environment where wealth generation, individual enterprise and business investment are actively encouraged and rewarded, where our primary concern is how to create wealth rather than how to distribute it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow an amendment I will be moving at a later stage in this debate. It will be an amendment to Senator Messner's amendment. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the words proposed to be added, add:
`(d) the government should be condemned for misleading Australians by claiming that meaningful tax cuts are being provided when they are in fact being neutralised by inflation; and
(e) the average income earner after 1 July 1987 will pay a marginal rate of tax of 40 per cent compared with the 30 per cent rate paid at the time the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983'.

That foreshadowed amendment strikes at the very heart of fraud involved in this Government's so-called tax cuts. Let us deal with this fraud. The Budget Papers reveal that total tax in this Budget will increase by $6.5 billion, or 11 per cent. That tax is rising to pay for the continuing increase in government spending which it has sought to hide by talking about its significant spending cuts. The Senate is well aware-but unfortunately many members of the Australian public have been deceived-that Federal Government spending is to increase to a record level in real terms this year even after accounting for inflation. That is why we need increased tax revenue. Clearly, the Government is setting off on a course which is improper, reckless and incredibly dangerous because by increasing its spending it is forced not only to increase taxes, as we have seen from the Budget Papers, but also to be a large borrower, to have a large impact on the money markets and worsen those factors which are bringing about the many economic problems which are manifested mainly in our disastrous external account-in the $32,000 a minute rate at which we are going into debt as a result of importing more than we export.

Let us look at this total taxation revenue, at this need of the Government because it will not cut its own spending. All it cut in the highly publicised, so-called Budget cuts was what it planned to spend, not what it was spending. This increased spending which is up 6.9 per cent, or about $4.8 billion, is to be financed by increased taxes. These are not just taxes on big companies or rich people but taxes on ordinary Australians. Let us take pay as you earn income taxpayers as an example. The net pay as you earn income tax collection this year, according to the Budget Papers, will go up by $2.6 billion even after the so-called tax cuts about which the Government is trumpeting in this legislation. Those are cuts on which at one stage it had hoped to wrest an early election if its other misdemeanours had not caught up with it with the result that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been awarded the accolade of being the second-worst Treasurer in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is working on becoming the worst.
—As my colleague says, he is doing so and he is doing very well.
—He wants to be at both ends of the scale.

—Yes, that is accurate. I would like to look at both ends of the tax scale pretty smartly. It is in the tax scale, apart from the scale of competence as a Treasurer, that we see an interesting contribution from the man whose greatest participation to the debate on tax in general has been the way that he has been a benefits rorter. The Treasurer's living away from home arrangements are extraordinary from a man who tells other people to behave but he fails to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Net pay as you earn taxation from ordinary Australian wage earners will go up in the Budget by $2.6 billion or 10.4 per cent despite the so-called tax cuts. Theoretically, these tax cuts will diminish the revenue that the Government would have had by about $1.4 billion. But how significant is that when the Government will still take $2.6 billion more in pay as you earn deductions? The increase for people who do not pay a pay as you earn tax but pay tax in other ways will be almost 15 per cent. This will happen despite the fact that farmers, a very big proportion of that group, will have much reduced incomes because of the disastrous consequences of both Government policy, which has belted farmers non-stop, and the difficulties with their terms of trade.

Those figures indicating what the ordinary taxpaying Australian will be hit with excludes the Medicare levy. The levy is to be increased, effective from 1 December, from one per cent to 1.25 per cent of taxable income. As a result, the Medicare collections will increase by 23 per cent-by $1.6 billion. In the list of other taxes we see huge increases. The prescribed payments taxes are up $750m or 46 per cent. In going through the taxes in the Budget which hit Australians we see enormous amounts, multi-millions of dollars-$6.5 billion-of tax increases overall. That is an 11 per cent rise to pay for the Government's determination to keep spending, spending and spending on its programs which it refuses to cut. That is why the Opposition has continually said: The only way to have genuine tax reform is to cut government spending.

This Government has neither the courage nor the determination to face up to its own left wing and cut out this great volume of expenditure which results directly in these huge increases of tax collections despite this so-called and much trumpeted tax cut which will come in in December as a result of this legislation. We should remind ourselves that these tax cuts were supposed to come in in September. They should be here already. They were part of a deal with the people of Australia under which the Government said that the offset to the workers of Australia for not taking full indexation earlier this year would be the tax cuts. The Government was being reckless in encouraging even the wage rise that did take place at a time when Australia was pricing itself out of world markets. But a deal was done that this tax cut would take place in September to offset the 2 per cent cut in the rate of the indexation rise in April. This is yet another example of the Government's breaking its word.

This Government is simply untrustworthy. The Government should never have entered into that arrangement in the first place because it was only transferring the cost of that reduction in wages to a different group of people in a different way. It was making the business community pay a very large proportion of that tax cut. The tax cut is being financed by two things. Firstly, it is being financed by business taxes. This tax package is deliberately and determinedly anti-business, anti-investment and anti-employment and is helping to pay for the tax cuts. Secondly, the tax cut is financed from inflation, as Senator Messner pointed out. Fiscal drag and inflation are pushing people into higher tax brackets and making them pay higher total taxes despite the so-called tax cuts.

Let us look at the impact of these tax cuts on the average family, on single income families and on a single person. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two tables which I have shown to the Minister who was previously in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These figures show very clearly what has happened to average tax rates in regard to the single income earner with a dependent spouse and dependent children. The figures have been referred to by other speakers in the debate. They show, for example, that when the Hawke Government was first elected in March 1983, the average tax rate paid by such a person was 17.5 per cent. But after the July 1987 tax cut, that is, after this tax cut and the next cut, the average tax rate will be 20.5 per cent-a significant increase. That represents a serious worsening in the tax burden of the single income earner on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and dependent children. The table shows that the average tax rate had gone from 17.5 per cent in March 1983 to 19.4 per cent by the December 1984 election, a substantial rise. By June this year the rate had gone up to 21.6 per cent. The upcoming so-called tax cuts will reduce the average tax rate from 21.6 per cent to 20.6 per cent and the second round of tax cuts will knock down the rate a bit further to 20.5 per cent. But the reduction in the average tax rate from 21.6 per cent to 20.5 per cent reduces only slightly the huge rise that has occurred. So an enormous net increase in the average tax burden of a single income family on average weekly earnings has occurred under the Hawke Government. So let us hear no nonsense from the Government, particularly from the loquacious, if inaccurate, Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) about what a great job the Government is doing in cutting taxes. With the tax burden increasing at such a rate, the Government has no case. It is talking through its hat and maintaining a tradition set by the world's second worst Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: The marginal tax rate is showing an even more dramatic change. For example, the marginal tax rate for the type of family I have just discussed was 30 per cent in March 1983. It will be 40 per cent in July 1987 after the Government's so-called magnificent tax cuts. In other words, the marginal tax rate of someone on average weekly earnings will go up by something like a third. Yet the Government keeps trumpeting about the wonderful cuts that have taken place. Even after these tax cuts the average family will pay a much higher proportion of its income in income tax. One would need a further income tax cut of $15 a week to bring the income tax burden back to its March 1983 level for a person on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and dependent children. But we are not to get that $15. The Australian people have every right to say that they have been robbed of $15 a week by this Government, which has pushed them, deliberately, into higher tax brackets and then tried to pretend that it is doing something wonderful for them in reducing their tax rates. What a wonderful thing to do-to reduce people's tax rates so that they pay $15 a week more than they paid when this Government came to office.

Let us consider what this tax burden means. When the Government came to office in March 1983, $65 a week was the burden on such a family. By June 1986 it had risen to $101. By July next year, when these great tax cuts come in, it will still be $101. In other words, there will be no tax cut whatsoever in money terms as a result of these tax changes. That is because fiscal drag will push people into higher tax brackets. So people in that category are now paying $36 more a week than they were paying when the Hawke Government was elected. The question of the impact of all this on families, in particular, is very serious, because on top of the increase in personal income tax, there is also the increased Medicare levy, the new and increased wholesale taxes on many goods and massive increases in petrol excise. So across a whole range of activities there is a mounting burden which the present so-called tax cuts go nowhere near removing. They simply nibble a little at the edges.

As I said, the Government needs increasing revenues because it continues to spend more and more. Last year, for example, the rise in public sector demand, 4.1 per cent, was almost three-quarters greater than the 2.4 per cent rise in private sector demand. To what extent will public sector demand be cut this year if we are to have genuine tax cuts? One can have genuine tax cuts only if one cuts government spending. This year the Government is `fixing things' by `cutting' demand in the public sector. We have to acknowledge that the Government will diminish to some extent the rate of rise in public sector demand, but it will not really cut it. Public sector demand will rise this year by about 1.5 per cent. As a result of all these additional taxes and attacks, if you like, on the private sector's ability to operate, private sector growth, according to the Budget Papers, will be a minimal 0.5 per cent. In other words, the Government in the Budget Papers expected its demand to increase at three times the rate of private sector demand. Yet we heard a report from New York-as yet unconfirmed; the Government will not confirm it-that the Treasurer's senior adviser, Dr Barry Hughes, expects the 0.5 per cent growth in the private sector to be wiped out entirely. There will be no growth. So as a result of the anti-incentive activities of this Government and the taxes it has imposed on the business community there will be no growth in the private sector whatsoever. Yet public sector demand will increase by 1.5 per cent. Until governments genuinely cut their spending, which this Government refuses to do, they will not be able to cut taxes.

Let us face it, there is a desperate need for tax cuts. In the United States real tax cuts are going through Congress. Sweeping and genuine reforms in the United States are knocking down that country's present tax scales of between 11 per cent and 50 per cent to a much closer range of between 15 and 27 per cent or so. This means that the world's wealthiest country will have the lowest top tax rate in the developed world. Apparently, under this Government, we do not have the capacity to go down that sort of track.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are pretty shonky figures, and you know it.

—These figures come from the Economist magazine. If Senator Button wants to call that magazine shonky, he is quite at liberty to do so. The interesting thing is that the need for a tax revolt is clear cut. Apart from anything else, if the Australian Government insists on maintaining a tax rate based against ability and incentive at rates far above those existing, say in the United States, we are going to have a brain drain. People will go to countries where they are not oppressed by a government such as the one that Senator Button is such a proud member of. He keeps mouthing the need for incentive and for the private sector to invest more and do more, yet all his actions appear to be aimed at pushing people off-shore and getting rid of them if they are good, well paid or well rewarded. He wants them to work but not to be rewarded.

SPEECH.PARA: The dreadful thing that has happened in Australia, under governments of both persuasions-we have to recognise that-is that tax rates that were aimed at people who were rich now apply to people who are simply average income earners. That situation is intolerable. But what is even more intolerable is the Government pretending that it is doing something positive to solve that problem with a set of tax cuts which leaves those people paying so much more in marginal tax, average tax and in total tax. Back in 1956, 30 years ago, a taxpayer did not have to pay the top marginal tax rate until his income was eight times average weekly earnings. That income would be around $153,000 in today's dollars. The top rate now cuts in at less than double average weekly earnings, at about $35,000 per year.

To pay for these continuing increases in government spending, tax rates that used to be reserved for the very rich now hit middle Australians, totally destroying their incentive. That is one of the reasons why the Opposition, instead of going down the track that the Government has gone down, is looking at the whole question of tax and is examining the many suggestions that have been made. One suggestion that appeals to me is the three-tiered system for personal income tax, with a 24 per cent, a 30 per cent and a 40 per cent rate, which is certainly well below the sorts of rates that this Government is talking about. It is interesting to note that this Government is not promising to pursue this whole question of diminishing personal income tax rates, which has long been a central plank of the Opposition's tax policy. We are determined that incentive be restored into the tax system and that Australians on normal sorts of incomes should not be paying tax rates that in the past were reserved for people who were rich.

This creates the question, which has to be addressed, about what one does with the income in the tax free zone-up to about $5,000. This is a matter which I think governments of all persuasions should examine because, by having the exemption up to $5,000-odd, the exemption applies to people with large incomes as well as those with small incomes. The Government's failure to address this question of genuine tax reform of the rates is most unfortunate, parti-cularly in the context that it has pretended that it is set on a path of major tax reform.

The reality is that the Government has done nothing to reduce the tax burden, which is increasing, and has done nothing to bring about basic reforms. When the Treasurer tried to introduce indirect taxes last year in order to provide at least an opportunity of reducing personal income tax rates in a genuine way-that is, if the receipts of indirect tax were not spent on bigger and bigger government spending-he was rolled by his own Prime Minister in a secret meeting over at the Lakeside Hotel. This Government is not interested in genuine tax reform and is not interested in cutting the tax burden. We have seen why-because it is interested in increasing total government spending further and further. I wish to add to the amendment already moved by Senator Messner and, therefore, I will move:
At the end of the words proposed to be added, add:
`(d) the government should be condemned for misleading Australians by claiming that meaningful tax cuts are being provided when they are in fact being neutralised by inflation; and
(e) the average income earner after 1 July 1987 will pay a marginal rate of tax of 40% compared with the 30% rate paid at the time the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983'.

The reality is that this Government is the biggest taxing government in Australia's history; it is the biggest spending government in Australia's history; it is the breaker of more promises than any government in Australia's history; and it has the worst record of creating expectations which it has no intention of fulfilling than any government in Australia's history. Once again it is presenting a sham to this place in that the so-called tax cuts are, in fact, a method of diminishing at the edges what is a major increase in taxation revenue. I am certain that the people of Australia will not tolerate a continuation of the sort of sham that this Government has once again presented to them on tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speeches given so far by honourable senators opposite indicate that the Opposition believes that high tax rates were something that came in with this Government and that the percentage of the gross domestic product that went to tax was somehow made greater, in large proportions, since the present Government has been in power. I think Senator Maguire has already dealt with that matter very effectively by putting forward the Budget receipts of the Government in which Mr Howard was Treasurer. Those figures show that the tax proportion of GDP jumped from 23 per cent to 24.7 per cent during that period, which is not much at all below what it is now. If all the criticism that the Opposition has been making about the Government's approach in this area is correct, that criticism, those objections and that analysis are just as pertinent to the previous Government. Where does that get us? It gets us to the position that what we get from members of the Opposition all the time is a whole series of criticisms and propositions which can be easily made when the burden of office is not upon them, but which in any event is not replaced in any way by any proposition that could be dealt with here and now in debate.

SPEECH.PARA: A suggestion was made by Senator Michael Baume, in which he echoed points made by Senator Alston, that the Opposition will go in for indirect taxes-consumption taxes- and that it will load up with indirect taxes those items of everyday life such as bread, butter and sugar. It will load up with indirect taxes the average things that everybody needs. How is that going to help the average citizen of this land if he has to pay extra for his bread, milk, tea, orange juice and so on? How regressive is it when the Opposition says that from now on the person who earns big money, the person who can best afford to pay, is not going to have to pay, but the poor old pensioner, the person on a low income or the man who gets out and works for his bread by the sweat of his brow, is going to be loaded up by having his bread taxed. Senator Michael Baume should think about that because I do not believe he is the sort of person who will make the honest man who earns his bread by the sweat of his brow pay more for that bread. I am sure that if Senator Michael Baume thinks about that idea he will reject it. We should not apply a consumption tax in such areas. We must look once more at the progressive and enlightened journey that this Government has taken on the question of taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted for an orange juice tax and a flavoured milk tax.

—But we have not taxed bread, the basic staff of life, which the Opposition intends to tax. The Opposition says that taxes have not been lowered, but from 1 December 1986 the existing rate of tax on income above $12,600 will be reduced from 25 per cent to 24 per cent and the tax-free threshold will increase to $12,600. As Senator Maguire so eloquently pointed out before-a brilliant speech-the lowest income tax rate under the former Liberal-National Party Government was 30 per cent. Yet our lowest rate is to be 24 per cent and the threshold will increase to $12,600. To say that that is not a reduction in the taxation system is to defy reality. One can go through all sorts of machinations, add this up, reduce that, get the calculator out and tap the keys and go through the process of producing figures. But that is all pointless when one comes down to the reality of the income tax rate being reduced from the 30c in the dollar which it was under the former Fraser Government to the 24 per cent rate which it will be. In addition, the threshold will be increased to $12,600. The 30 per cent rate will reduce to 29 per cent and the next two rates of 46 per cent and 48 per cent will be reduced. The maximum rate in the future will be 49 per cent. That is a very significant and praiseworthy effort. I turn now to Senator Messner's amendment concerning the Income Tax Rates Bill. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) the Government's taxation policy, in particular its fringe benefits and capital gains taxes, is causing damage and confusion to business and farmers;
(b) the Government's failure to deliver tax cuts on 1 September 1986 as promised in 1985 has caused additional hardship to families; and
(c) this Government is the highest taxing Government in history, with tax receipts estimated to reach 25.5% of GDP''.

The whole emphasis of the amendment is on reducing damage to business and farmers. It is praiseworthy to seek to do that. But what about the ordinary working man? He is not mentioned specifically in that amendment as are the business community and the farming community. What is wrong with giving him a go? He is the very person the Opposition expects to get us out of the present difficulty. He is the person the Opposition expects to take cuts in wages, to accept wage freezes and to suffer the rigours and the shortcomings that the Opposition says are presently in this community. In view of that, is it not fair for the business community to contribute? I pause at this point to say that I have great praise for the major part of the business community and the farmers. Business should accept its responsibility. If the ordinary working man has to make sacrifices why should not business? Many a businessman no doubt wants to do that. But what happens when they want to invest in Australia? They are loyal, patriotic citizens interested in their fellow Australians. They want to invest in Australia to get us out of this taxation problem that is foreseen as a difficulty we will face in the future? The Age today carries a report of comments of the National Treasurer of the Liberal Party of Australia. It states:
Australian companies would be unwise to invest in Australia and would look overseas, Elders IXL chief Mr John Elliott told a Melbourne Management Week conference today.
Those businesses which were prepared to invest in Australia would be acting on `emotional rather than hard logical reasons', he told about 400 businessmen.

How are we as a nation to get out of our difficulties, to get over the problems that the Opposition says we have with these tax problems, if we do not get investment from business and if the National Treasurer of the Liberal Party goes around saying that business should not invest in Australia? Do Senator Parer and his colleagues accept that Australia should have a business community that will invest simply according to where the most opportune dollar will come from?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—Apparently that is his position. Concepts such as nationalism, patriotism and trying to help fellow Australians apparently should not be taken into account. Would Senator Parer accept that?
—Yes, and I think you would, too.

—I do not because I think that the business community, along with the work force, should make sacrifices. We have been called upon to make sacrifices, not only by the Government but also by members of the Opposition. They have criticised the union movement and berated the workers of this country for not making proper sacrifices. When one skerrick of sacrifice is called for from the business community the National Treasurer of the Liberal Party advises the Liberal Party, the National Party-the present Opposition-and the business community not to help Australia, not to show a patriotic streak, not to show any sort of compassion for their fellows but simply to go where they can get the best and quickest quid.
—Where is their sense of fair play?

—As Senator McIntosh asked, where is their sense of fair play? Those people call upon the workers of Australia to make all sorts of sacrifices, to accept wage freezes for years, to take a reduction in wages and put their shoulder to the wheel. As soon as any sacrifice is sought from those people they go immediately to ground and say that they have to get out of the country, abandon the land of their birth and invest elsewhere so that other people can enjoy the fruits which should properly benefit Australia. This point was very well picked up. It was referred to earlier today by Senator Alston. There is a comment in today's Age by Maximilian Walsh. Talking about the difference in approach between the American business community and the Australian business community and referring to the American firm Reebok, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Reebok and its runaway success is an example of why the distinguishing feature of homo Americanis economicus is positivism. In contrast, the Australian equivalent often appears infected with congenital melancholia.

Why is Australian business so depressed? Because the National Treasurer of the Liberal Party keeps coming out and saying that it has to be depressed. That is the great difficulty we face. Criticism of this Government sits ill in the mouths of members of the Liberal Party when their own party executive apparently is on a course destined to bring this country to ruin by urging that businessmen not invest unless investment is absolutely on their terms. To be fair to the trade union movement, it says that it would make the sacrifices required to bring prosperity to Australia if the business community would do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did it say that?

—That was stated by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Simon Crean, last night. The answer he apparently gets is: `No, you make all the sacrifices and we will make none'. There has been great criticism, of course, about the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. At the same time, great play has been made about the taxation system in the United States of America which, of course, has a very high capital gains tax which is not indexed for inflation.
—That is where Elliott is investing.

—That is right. It has death duties and gift duties. Of course, it is the highest debtor nation in the world. The sort of proposition that is put by the Opposition is that we should follow America down the line, become the highest debtor nation in the world, impose death duties, gift duties and, of course, capital gains duties which are not indexed. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot in one breath say that we should look at America in terms of income tax rates, and in the next breath ignore it in terms of all sorts of other taxes. What we must do is look at the whole system. When one looks at the whole system, Australia comes out very well. That is not acknowledged by those on the other side. They simply select figures-that is what has happened this morning-to make out a proposition which, on their figures and their arguments, does not stand up. The lowest tax rate that could be delivered by their proposed future Prime Minister could not come anywhere near the lowest tax rate which has been, and will be, delivered by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that should be mentioned about the tax package is this: The income tax Act will be amended to increase the taxable income level, at or below which the maximum pensioner rebate of $250 is available, from $5,595 to $5,914 in 1986-87, and to $6,142 in 1987-88 and subsequent years. The maximum levels of the beneficiary rebates will also be increased from $220 to $280 for married beneficiaries and from $170 to $190 for other beneficiaries. That is another aspect of the tax package which must be looked at. The argument to date mostly has been about how it affects those in the higher income brackets. This tax package delivers something for those in the community who are in receipt of the lowest incomes. That is the sort of thing that ought to be brought to notice very strongly, because it is the sort of thing that the Opposition keeps ignoring. It has been interested only in the higher tax rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Selective quotes.

—Selective quotes; that is right. It says, of course, that it will keep the tax rates that we have introduced under our tax reforms yet it will reduce the source of its money-except, perhaps, for some fairly savage impositions of consumer taxes. But if one looks at the explanatory notes of the original legislation on the fringe benefits tax, one finds, for example, that we are looking at collecting $330m in 1986-87, $540m in 1987-88 and $625m in 1988-89. Those are great sums of money which have to be replaced from somewhere. From which areas will the Opposition collect that money? Will it cut expenditure? If it cuts expenditure, where is the detailed list of those expenditure cuts? It is all very well to put forward a series of figures and propositions during debate. I submit that the sorts of things that should be put forward are hard policies, hard programs and hard figures, so that the debate can take place properly.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not fair for the Opposition to talk vaguely about the areas in which it may make cuts. It says: `Expenditure is a problem. Let us cut expenditure'. In what areas will that expenditure be cut? It will be very interesting to hear from those Opposition senators who will speak in this debate-Senator Watson, Senator Short and Senator Crichton-Browne-the areas in which cuts will be made and the extent to which those cuts will be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then their Leader will deny it, because they do not have policies; they are bereft.

—They do not have policies; that is quite right. They are bereft of policies. The next point that should be made about the propositions put by the other side is that they are developed on a false basis. If one looks, for example, at the company tax and profitability rate from 1979 to 1982, compared with the rate in 1985-86, one will see that the percentage of tax paid by companies in the last year of the previous Government was 25.5 per cent of the gross operating surplus. In 1985-86 the tax rate as a percentage of the gross operating surplus was 18 per cent. So the imposition of tax on companies by this Government is much lower than it was under the previous Government. I again make the point--
—That has nothing to do with anything. The whole basis of the surplus has changed.

—All I am saying is this: Opposition senators cite figures and make all sorts of submissions about the tax Act. They simply produce figures which are quite selective. I am illustrating that the Government can produce all sorts of figures to indicate that its system is much better than the previous Government's system. What the Opposition is doing the whole time is to machinate, using a calculator, to prove certain figures. All I am saying is that if one chooses other figures, one can prove to the contrary. Opposition senators have not been able to disprove that the tax rates, as set out in this legislation, are quite clearly lower than they were when they were in government. The top rate of 60 per cent has been reduced. The bottom rate of 30 per cent has been reduced. Opposition senators can go through all sorts of twists and turns and, as I say, get out the calculator and the books to try to prove that in some way the rate is increasing. But when one looks at the actual figures it is clear that this Government's tax approach has been very reformist.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that Senator Maguire made-again, the Opposition has not really mentioned it-is that the tax collected through such mechanisms as the fringe benefits tax is not tax which will go to government expenditure; it is tax which will go to allow for cuts in the tax rates. The argument really is about who should pay. The Opposition keeps repeating that only a particular section should pay. I am not referring only to who should make sacrifices, and the Opposition's approach to business, compared with its approach to the ordinary working person. The Opposition is prejudiced not only in that regard but also in regard to who should pay the taxes. The Opposition believes that persons who have for years enjoyed fringe benefits in some way should continue to enjoy those fringe benefits and those who have been deprived as a result should continue to be deprived. It says that a person who receives his income in cash-a person who receives income in the way in which most people in Australia receive income-should have to bear the burden of those who receive their income by way of fringe benefits, such as a free car, free education for their children and free credit cards.

If one looks at the broad thrust of the tax package-which, in my view, one should-as distinct from particular examples which may be produced to show how a particular tax works unjustly in a particular instance, one will see that this Government has produced a package which will introduce tax cuts, and which is a very benign system. I think that Senator Messner would agree if he thought about it in broad terms rather than concentrating on particular examples, which we can always produce to show that a general rule acts in a bad way. In other words, to take a particular example, say, of somebody who is given a house in a remote area and the fringe benefits tax adversely affects it, is something that can be done in respect of any proposition that is put forward. On the other hand we should look at the general thrust, which is simply this: For anybody who receives remuneration, whether in cash or in cash and some other form, that remuneration should be subject to its proper income tax rate, and I think most people would agree with that proposition.

Capital gains tax has been condemned in this place and it was stated that it should be abolished. Again, its abolition leads to all sorts of injustices. No doubt we can point to examples here and there where a capital gains tax may, in a particular instance, seem too burdensome. However, what about a situation where two people are earning, say, something like $60,000 a year and one person is able to convert $40,000 of it into capital, upon which there is no tax, and the other person has to pay tax on the whole $60,000? Is that fair? When it is put that way, it is quite clear that it is not and it becomes quite clear that that sort of tax is a reasonable tax for people to pay.

As I have said, if one looks at the whole tax package and at the thrust of the system rather than at the edges, where one might find some specific examples that the whole tax package works badly, one can see that its thrust is good. Considering the sorts of propositions put forward by the Opposition, which tries to get away from the reality that there are tax cuts that will benefit people across the board and that this is the most major tax reform that has occurred in this country in living memory, one is entitled to say that this is a measure which the Opposition could not introduce. What it is now doing is trying to hack away and attack a system which is much better than any that it ever proposed. It is a system which stands against very vague propositions and very vague criticisms in the sense that that criticism is not worked out in specifics. This legislation will bring benefits across the board and it deserves support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney is not only a great lawyer but is also becoming a great parliamentarian. Time and again the Australian Labor Party pulls him into this chamber at an awkward time in order to defend the indefensible. I admire not only the honourable senator's humour, his knowledge of the law and his parliamentary tactics, but also his stamina. Time and again he has to come in here, under great difficulty and great duress, and defend the indefensible. I thank the honourable senator for his contribution to this debate. It has been interesting and informative.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge Senator Cooney's Party's contribution to taxing orange juice. I acknowledge his Party's contribution to taxing flavoured milk, and so on, and I acknowledge his frankness in saying that his Party has not yet levied a tax on bread. After all, bread is the staple diet of the ordinary working man. I believe that Senator Cooney has a great understanding of the ordinary working man and a great feeling towards such people, but I remind him that it is those very people who are now walking away from the Labor Party. I commend the honourable senator on his ability to try to bring them back to the fold. As the honourable senator well knows, the needs of the ordinary working man go well beyond the requirement of bread. From the honourable senator's knowledge of his needs and as a devoutly religious person, he would also know that man cannot live by bread alone. I remind honourable senators opposite that man also needs water from time to time. However, the Labor Party has now levied a fringe benefits tax on fresh water that is provided to the people of the defence forces who work at Woomera. So the Labor Party is getting pretty close to taxing bread.

On a more serious or less flippant note, the Senate is debating the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986, and the Medicare Levy Bill 1986. The Medicare Levy Bill will increase the Medicare levy by 25 per cent. We have been told that this range of Bills is aimed at producing tax cuts. There are a few tax cuts, but we do not hear about the people who will be paid $4m or $5m to sell this package. Fancy having to sell a package of tax cuts to the Australian people! The Government has to pay an advertising agency $4m or $5m to tell Australians how much better off they will be because of the tax cuts. What a waste of taxpayers' money! What a futile exercise!

The Labor Party is singing its own praises about tax reductions, but a simple analysis will show that taxes have not gone down; they have gone up. No wonder the Government has to employ consultants to try to con the Australian people when taxes have actually gone up under this Labor Government. I remind the Senate that not only did the Labor Party fail to deliver the income tax cuts when they were promised, in September, but also next year the prospect of the remainder of the package being delivered is remote indeed. One only has to analyse the Budget to find out the impossibility of the Government delivering the remainder of the tax cuts unless it bites deeply into expenditure and unless it finds some new form of revenue next year.

The previous Budget was a short term expedient measure. It was geared for an early election that did not come off because of a slip of the tongue by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Next year we will be faced with the prospect of higher, not lower, taxation unless we can see major reductions in expenditure. I cannot see a Labor government tackling such difficult problems when it has a history of walking away from difficult issues. As all my colleagues have said in this debate, and it stands out: The present Labor Government is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia, raising 25.5 per cent of gross national product in taxes.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development tells us that the share of total Australian taxation which comes from incomes and profits as a percentage of the total tax burden is amongst the highest of the OECD countries. On the one hand the Government is instructing advertising agencies to tell the Australian people how much better off the electorate will be, yet the Australian Government is amongst the highest taxing governments of the OECD countries. We will not be told of that in the footage to the television commercials. Our percentage of total tax revenue collected by taxes on wages and profits is the fourth highest of those of the OECD countries. We are not a low tax country by any means.

Even after both stages of the tax cuts have been implemented, the one for December and the one after that, the marginal and average tax imposed upon average earners-the very people to whom Senator Cooney was appealing, the people who live on bread and water-will be higher than when the Hawke Government first came to office in March 1983. How does that sound? The average tax rate and the marginal tax rate of the average wage earner will be higher after this tax package is introduced and after the promises have been fulfilled than when the Hawke Government first came to power. Under the last Liberal Government Budget the people of Australia were taxed $44,000m. In this year's Budget they are taxed $71,000m, an increase of 61 per cent in the space of four years.

Of course, the Government is trying to reduce the deficit by imposing higher taxes. The average weekly wage earner with a wife and two children-these are Senator Cooney's constituents, the poor ordinary bloke with a wife and two kids in receipt of average or slightly below average weekly earnings-will be paying 20.5 per cent of his income in tax, as opposed to only 17.5 per cent of his total earnings in the final year of the Fraser Government. This does not even include the one per cent Medicare levy which is to be increased by 25 per cent as a result of this package of Bills. This increase is not mentioned when the Government talks about tax cuts. We never see that mentioned in the television footage in which the Government tells us how good its tax package is.

The Income Tax Rates Bill will declare the rates of tax payable by individuals and trustees for 1986-87 and subsequent years. It will basically give effect to some nominal personal tax cuts as announced in the September 1985 tax package. We have had to wait a long time for those tax cuts, but we are used to doing that under a Labor administration. The Bill will allow the tax free threshold to operate only on a pro rata basis in certain circumstances. But what is the Government going to do? It is going to tax the youngsters who are just leaving school. The kids who are getting their first pay packet will be worse off from a tax point of view than their mums who stay at home and do a bit of occasional work. The Government is going to attack them on the threshold of their careers. The Government is after the votes of the 17- and 18-year-olds. However, I do not think these people will be too impressed when they get their first pay and find that they are being taxed on a basis which is far more savage than that which applies to their mothers who do a little bit of part time work.

By 1 July 1987-and that is not too far off-approximately two million taxpayers will have moved out of this new 29 per cent tax bracket into the 40 per cent tax bracket. Two million people will go from 29 per cent to 40 per cent. By 1 July about 50 per cent of all taxpayers will be paying the 40 per cent rate or even higher. Yet, the Government is talking about tax cuts. I can tell the Government that it is camouflaging these cuts pretty well. Australia's unacceptably high inflation rate is responsible for tax bracket creep-the secret collector on which the Labor Party relies. It needs high inflation so that it can collect progressively more and more taxes. The Government is progressively reducing the real disposable income of ordinary wage earners by pushing them into higher and higher tax brackets as their income increases. So, in the absence of indexing taxes to inflation, bracket creep-and we all know that term-will erode the ability of Australians to save and to invest in productive enterprises. We are taking away from ordinary Australians their ability to save for the future and to try and improve their lot in life.

I think the 1 December tax cuts will come at last. We have waited a long time for them. The Government has procrastinated and put them off. We will get the tax cuts but maybe we will not get the second instalment. Of course, the first hire purchase payment is always the easiest one to make. The other ones become harder to meet. So the December tax cut will provide only a temporary aberration from the tax bracket creep that arises from the Australian Labor Party's inflationary policies.

We are talking about tax reductions. But if we look into this matter carefully, we find company tax is not going down-it is going up from 46c to 49c in the dollar. I have said before that we are not going to attract the productive investment that is waiting out there in Asia, the United States of America and Europe if we have a 49c in the dollar primary company tax rate. But we will get a lot of the speculative money coming in to buy and sell land, to buy up the farm and to buy a bit of real estate. But this money will not be invested in productive Australian enterprises-enterprises that will provide jobs for Australian people.

At a time when the Labor side puts so much emphasis on reducing personal income taxes, I think it is hypocritical that in this package the Labor Party could have a Bill which increases the Medicare levy by 25 per cent-from one per cent to 1.25 per cent. Of course, this increase is counter to the 1984 election promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) not to increase the levy. Not only that, but this idea was reinforced by none other than the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) as late as 7 March 1986, just a few months back, when he said that no consideration at all would be given to changing the one per cent Medicare levy and that the Government would be keeping to its election promise. It is no wonder that the people are becoming increasingly disenchanted with the Australian Labor Party because its leadership fails to keep its word and deliver on its promises.

We have become accustomed to seeing blow-out after blow-out. Such scenarios are all too evident in Labor's administration of the economy. In the area of Medicare we have also seen a massive blow-out and explosion of costs. This levy is going to raise only $1,645m, leaving the Government to finance a $2,355m shortfall. In effect, if the Government were fully to finance this levy through taxation-and really it is financing it through taxation because that shortfall has to be met indirectly by taxation-the levy would actually be equal to 3 per cent. So, in reality, the levy is simply an additional form of income tax.

The worrying part about the Medicare levy is that the gap between the levy and the cost of providing the service of Medicare continues to widen at an accelerating rate. As a result of this program, Australians will have a decreased choice of health care. We now have a cumbersome system with burgeoning cost. Only those who can afford to maintain private health care can now have a guaranteed access to a hospital bed when needed. So low income earners especially are now faced with long waits in public hospital queues. These are the sorts of people that I care about and that Senator Walsh possibly does not. Furthermore, the removal of the subsidy on private hospital beds I think is a false economy and a further implementation of socialist policies. I think it will drive up health insurance costs, forcing more and more people into the public health system which is unable to cope with demand.

I had not intended to talk about the fringe benefits tax et cetera but as my colleagues on the Government side have already done so I therefore believe that I should respond. It has been said that the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, et cetera, have played an integral part in causing some of the temporary decreases in tax rates, but they are certainly anti-business. A medium sized Australian company which has to provide telephones to certain of its employees for call-outs in the case of accident or for some other form of quick service, has had trouble in working out the fringe benefit tax component for the provision of those telephones. Do honourable senators know what the Commissioner of Taxation suggested? He suggested that to overcome the problem the company install a separate telephone, with a separate telephone number, in each employee's house. Not only is this going to add to costs but it will not even solve the problem because we all know that if the wife wants to ring up the mother-in-law in Melbourne she will not use the private phone, she will use the company phone. That advice is farcical. What has really happened is that the Labor Government's fringe benefits tax has legitimised the payment of perks to people on higher incomes but the real sufferers are those on the bottom and middle income levels. Senator Cooney's mates who are earning over $40,000 will get more and more fringe benefits because it will be cheaper for a company to give them fringe benefits than to pay them an additional amount. What is the Government going to do to these poor little blokes? The tax is becoming a hidden cost on the employees as well as the employers. The employees are the very ones who are supposed to benefit, to get away from this fringe benefits tax, but it is a tax on employees. Employers, of course, will pass on their costs in the form of higher wages.

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics about 58 per cent of lower and middle income earners get some sort of fringe benefit. It may not be much, but it all adds to the cost. A local charity, a community organisation, in Canberra will have to pay $2,000 fringe benefits tax. But what are the bosses doing? They are reducing the number of salary increases and bonuses. They have taken away these benefits and so the sufferers are those lower and middle income earners, not those on higher salaries because they will get increased perks. Those on lower incomes will have the tax absorbed within their industry.

Apart from that, we have also had instances where the employer has passed the tab back to the employee. The tax on company cars is another example of where the ordinary person on average income will be far worse off. Although there is an accounting classification for the fringe benefits tax the Public Service has effectively been quarantined from it. There is no cashing out in the public sector as there is in the private sector. I believe this is an abhorrent tax and therefore I stand with my Leader in saying that the Labor Party's fringe benefits tax has to be amended in the immediate future but that when we come to power it will certainly be abolished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills we are debating at the moment, the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986, the Income Tax Bill 1986 and the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986, along with the change to the Medicare legislation are the principal legislative proposals giving effect to the taxation measures announced by the Government in the Budget in August. The first thing I think we ought to be saying about these Bills is that they should never have been introduced. Had the Government pursued responsible, competent economic policies, these tax changes and tax increases would not have been necessary. They are being introduced simply as a product of a spendthrift wanton socialist Government that is driving Australia towards bankruptcy.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is the largest taxing and the highest taxing government that Australia has had since Federation. This year taxation receipts will account for 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product. That is a record level of taxation. Why is this taxation being levied? It is being levied for one reason only, and that is because the Australian Labor Party Government is unable to restrain its ever inherent need for further funds for its spending sprees. That case can be made right across the board. Look at the advertising campaigns, the media junkets, the paying off of friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions movement, the grants for various pursuits, and the administrative and bureaucratic bungles that are going on everywhere throughout Labor's activities. I am absolutely staggered to see in today's Press the admission by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the Government is in fact considering a high flying national advertising campaign to sell its tax reform package, a campaign which is estimated to cost $2m. Mr Acting Deputy President, that is $2m of your money, my money and the money of every Australian which we pay in taxes. It is not coming out of the coffers of the Labor Party, it is coming out of the pockets of Australian taxpayers.

Even the lead-up to this announcement yesterday by the Treasurer has been fraught with the confusion and misinformation that has become the hallmark of this Government. Only a few days ago the Minister responsible for government advertising, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, told Parliament that the suggestion of such an advertising campaign was: `A flight of fantasy'. No sooner had he said that than he was contradicted by the then Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, who said that the Government was considering a campaign although planning was in the `very early stages'. Yet yesterday Mr Keating admitted that three advertising agencies had already been approached. He tried to defend this campaign and this decision by saying that it was within `established procedures'. That is nonsense. No government in the history of Australia has spent so much of other people's money in trying to promote itself in terms of the campaigns that it has been pursuing. They are essentially political campaigns that have nothing to do with educating Australians about the activities of government. Indeed the reports in relation to this latest campaign show quite clearly that in the main it is not going to advise people about the forthcoming December tax cuts. It is understood that the main thrust will be the unpopular fringe benefits tax.

A great deal has been said about the fringe benefits tax in both chambers and on both sides of the Parliament for a considerable time. I do not propose to go over the detail of that today but I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate a statement very much in support of what we, on this side of politics, have been saying about this anti-business, anti-incentive, anti-job fringe benefits tax that is being perpetrated on the Australian community. I quote from the latest publication of the Federated Clerks Union of Australia-hardly a radical left wing union; it is a very responsible union. The August issue of The Clerk, its newsletter, has an article which is headed `Fringe taxes cost jobs'. It is such a significant statement that I will read it to the Senate. It states:
Jobs of workers in their thousands are threatened by the Fringe Benefits Tax in weakening investment and in pushing up costs which trigger buyer resistance to higher prices.
It is precisely the thing that this coalition has been saying ever since the fringe benefits tax was first mooted. The article goes on:
Taxes and charges are a cause of a fall of 170,000 car sales this year, a loss of almost $2 billion in retail turnover.
More than 80,000 people are employed by car and component manufacturers, plus another 100,000 in automotive distribution and retailing.
An estimated 250,000 swell their ranks in related industries that supply and service the motor industry.
The Fringe Benefits Tax bites everywhere in primary, tertiary and manufacturing industries, striking at the employment security of blue collar and white collar workers alike.
Here comes the significant point although all those other points are very pertinent as well. The article goes on:
At its August meeting the ACTU Executive said:
The Fringe Benefits Tax is wider and greater than anticipated.
In some ways the tax is inconsistent with assurances that were given to unions by the Federal Government.
The ACTU will seek to resolve the difficulties confronting workers in retail, building and banking industries and other similar problems brought about by the Fringe Benefits Tax.

No better confirmation has been given anywhere in anything I have read in the last two or three months about the fringe benefits tax and the inequities and the cost of that in terms of investment and employment in Australia than that article that appears in The Clerk newsletter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the sort of nonsense one reads somewhere or other about every tax.

—The Minister may say that, but I am sure that the Federated Clerks Union, all the other unions, and members of the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions will be very pleased to note his comments.
—Fancy imposing those taxes while choking off demand with a tight monetary policy.
—That is right.
—You are a lackey of the ACTU.

—At least it appears, I say to the Minister, that the Australian people are waking up to which party in Australian politics is the party which is concerned with the whole community; the low income earners, the medium income earners, as well as those who did not earn income at all. It has taken Australians a little while to wake up to the fact that the Government is beholden to vested interests in this community that has led to policies of lack of restraint, that have put this country very rapidly on the road to bankruptcy. The Minister knows that as well as I do. He has not been able to hold the line in his portfolio and in the job he has been given by his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) travelled the length and breadth of this country touting his much vaunted trilogy promises. One fundamental element of that trilogy was that there would be no increase in the overall level of taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product, either over the life time of the Parliament or during the first year the Budget was brought down under a re-elected Hawke Government. The tax leg of the trilogy has been broken in each of the two Budgets that have been brought down since the election in 1984. There have been increases in the percentage of tax collected as a proportion of GDP in each of these two years, despite the unequivocal commitment that the Prime Minister gave the nation in trying to buy votes at the time of that election. In 1984-85, the percentage of tax to GDP was 25 per cent. That was the figure that was not going to be exceeded, yet in the first Budget alone it went to 25.2 per cent in the actual out turn and that became apparent only through careful reading of the Budget Papers. The Government did not even have the courage to announce that it had broken its trilogy promise. This year the figure is forecast to be 25.5 per cent, and that is a figure based on a very reliable and-to coin a word of which Senator Walsh is very prone-shonky forecast for 1986-87. That forecast will not be fulfilled. When the forecast is not fulfilled it will lead to an even larger breaking of the trilogy, the unequivocal promises so-called, than is already admitted.

In 1986-87 Mr Keating will break the trilogy tax commitment. He will break it by not far short of $1.5 billion collected in a raft of new tax collections to try to go some way to meeting that great yawning chasm between government spending and government revenue. That has nothing to do with the economic growth of this country. Those tax increases are cold, deliberate decisions taken of necessity because of this Government's inability to act competently and restrainedly in terms of its expenditure commitments. Not only that, but the Prime Minister himself has already laid the ground work for another dishonouring of the trilogy next financial year, 1987-88. As recently as 27 August he said:
The decision regarding the tax share of GDP in the 1987-88 Budget will be taken in the light of circumstances at that time.
Nothing could be more clear-the Prime Minister is trying to give himself an out in terms of yet a further breaking of his commitment next year.

That is not the end of the story by any means. The state of the economy is much worse than those comments portray. The promised September tax cuts have been deferred to December this year. The Treasurer has again broken his promise. He has done it before and he will do it again; there is no guarantee that he will not. Even if these tax cuts are granted the average and marginal taxation paid by Australians, whether they be single or a supporting spouse with two children, will be higher than when this Government came to power in March 1983. The average tax rate in March 1983 was less than 23 per cent. The marginal rate was 30 per cent. In both cases, even after the second stage of the delivery of the promised tax cuts, those rates will then be 24.5 per cent and 40 per cent.

A married couple with one breadwinner and two children paid $52.12 a week income tax when the coalition left office in 1983. In December 1986 after the first of the Government's much vaunted tax cuts that same family will be paying $93.43 a week, and after July 1987, that is after the second stage of the tax cuts, the tax paid will be even higher-it will be $94.50 a week. That compares with $52.12 a week that was the tax applying when the Fraser Government lost office in 1983. In other words, there will be a massive increase-almost a doubling of the $42.38 a week-in tax for the average taxpaying family over the period of the Labor Government's administration. To call the tax changes that this Government is proposing for December this year-three months late-and for the middle of next year `tax cuts' in any real sense is an absolute and total hoax and fraud on the Australian community. TALK.START.PARA: —No fewer than 14 new tax initiatives which have been taken have resulted in increases in tax levels by Labor since it came to office. Those tax increases have been fraught with anomalies and loaded on to the productive sector of the community and, through that, have had wide-ranging negative application to each and every person in Australia. We have seen the sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juices and increased wholesale taxes, and petrol excise over the last 18 months alone has increased by well over 100 per cent. We have seen the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the entertainment tax, the lump sum superannuation tax, a whole range of new wholesale taxes--
—And soon the gold tax.

—And soon, perhaps, the gold tax, which we-including Senator Crichton-Browne, of course-are totally committed to rejecting if it is brought in by Labor. We have seen the automatic biennial indexation of excise rates, the abolition of concessional expenditure rebates, a wine tax, an excise tax on intermediate and new oil and, finally, a bureaucratic substantiation of employment expenses. It is small wonder that Australians are sensitive to the tax issue-it is the most sensitive political issue in Australia today, as the latest survey results indicate- because they have been deluged by an orgy of taxation by an avaricious government unable to control its housekeeping. The latest Roy Morgan gallup poll shows that Australians rank taxation reductions as the most important issue; 36.3 per cent of Australians rank it as No. 1. That is by far the most important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other Bills that we are debating is the Medicare Levy Bill, whereby the Medicare levy will rise from one per cent to 1 1/4 per cent of taxable income. That increase in levy leaves little room for doubt that Labor is unable to deliver effective health care at a reasonable cost. It is yet another example of a broken promise. In the 1984 policy speech the Prime Minister said:
And now I give this undertaking-that for the term of our next government the Medicare levy will not be increased.
As recently as February this year the Prime Minister said:
I affirm that the Government has no plans to change the Medicare arrangements.
The following month, in March, Dr Blewett said:
Well the Prime Minister has made it quite clear at the election and in a recent statement that there's no consideration of changing the Medicare levy.

Yet five months later, in August, the Budget brought down a 25 per cent increase in the Medicare levy. When Medicare was introduced on 1 February 1984 the one per cent levy on taxable income provided everyone with three health insurance benefits: First, Medicare benefits of at least 85 per cent of schedule fees; secondly, free treatment in a public hospital; and, thirdly, subsidies of up to $40 a day in a private hospital.

On 1 October 1986, after a 25 per cent increase in that levy, we now get for that higher levy a reduction in benefits. Everyone continues to receive medical benefits, but the benefits have been reduced. Fees in public hospitals will increase, as will the gap between Medicare benefits and schedule fees for hospital patients. The old gap was up to $10 per service. The new gap is up to $20 per service. People with private health insurance must now pay in a public or repatriation hospital. No one receives a private hospital subsidy. The transfer of costs from government to the private sector in this health area now amounts to $450m a year.
