I once more draw Senator Walsh's attention to that standing order and ask him to relate his remarks to the question and not to engage in debate on the subject matter.

—Certainly, Mr President. The plain fact is that the fringe benefits tax will have no effect upon 85 per cent of farmers. What the Queensland Premier has promised to do is in fact a stunt. It is just another excuse for handing out largesse to National Party apparatchiks-taxpayers' money at 4 per cent interest, funds provided by the taxpayer, lent out by the Queensland Government-on the pretence that it will help farmers pay the fringe benefits tax when 85 per cent of farmers are not affected by the fringe benefits tax at all. According to the report, the proposed loans are to be administered through the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. I do not know where that institution gets its funds from but I will be doing everything I possibly can to ensure that Queensland no longer siphons off any Federal money that is designed for other purposes into that particular slush fund, as it has done in many other cases.

—I raise a point of order. That slush fund, as Senator Walsh refers to it, is clearly a department or a corporation of the Queensland Government. It is the Queensland Industry Development Corporation where the money comes from.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the Minister's answer in Question Time yesterday that the Government has no evidence that the Soviet Union has deployed weapons systems in Vietnam which directly endanger Australia. I ask the Minister: Does this not contradict the answers given by the Minister for Defence to the honourable member for Hawker to questions on notice Nos 171 and 172 in May 1985? Is it not the case that the situation outlined in those questions and answers is still the same in terms of Soviet operations? Could he remind the Senate of those details? Is it not, therefore, the case that Soviet forces operating out of Vietnam threaten potentially both our sea lines of communication and our territory, in the latter case through refuelled bombers or nuclear-weapon carrying submarines deployed from Cam Ranh Bay in either the Pacific or Indian Oceans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that Senator Teague is referring to some answers to questions on notice in which Mr Beazley identified the understood Soviet naval and air presence at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam. It is undoubtedly the case that there is a substantial store of armaments and weaponry there located. The argument simply boils down to one essentially about semantics-whether or not one regards the capability at Cam Ranh Bay as being of a character that directly endangers Australia, to use the language that I employed yesterday. Mr Beazley is certainly of the view that it cannot be so described.

ANSWER.PARA: I am in the process of seeking a more comprehensive response from the Minister in order that I can perhaps argue the case in the terms that the honourable senator would prefer, but there is no argument at all about the stationing of quite a substantial arsenal at Cam Ranh Bay. The question is about the strategic significance of that so far as Australia is directly concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. The Minister referred to semantics, but I ask whether it is the case that the Minister misled the Senate yesterday in referring to the absence of such weapons systems in Vietnam. Is the statement of the Minister for Defence incorrect?

—Senator Teague is getting over-excited, rather like Senator Chaney. It must be these Friday sittings. The reality is that what I said yesterday is perfectly straightforward. What I said was that the Government has no evidence that the Soviet Union has deployed weapons systems in Vietnam which directly endanger Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is it true, as claimed in a recent Press report, that petrol prices in Sydney have increased by 8c per litre as a result of the Government's import parity pricing policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not true. In an article in the Daily Telegraph yesterday-indeed, I have heard subsequent radio reports-the increase has been put at as high as 11c per litre. The latest adjustment to import parity prices on 1 October in fact resulted in an increase in the wholesale price of petrol of only 0.17c per litre. That was actually less than the 0.25c per litre which I had indicated was likely to occur at the time of that parity price increase. That followed because the Prices Surveillance Authority used a different exchange rate.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the increase in petrol prices in Sydney that is attributable to the import parity pricing policy, obviously those reports are wildly astray. To the extent that the increase has occurred in various locations around Sydney-in fact, I gather the greater metropolitan area-the cause of it is that the oil companies, once again, are changing their marketing practices and discontinuing the price support which had enabled very extensive discounting in the Sydney metropolitan area. This phenomenon of discount wars breaking out, keeping the price down, then retreating and there being substantial price increases, has been a phenomenon which has been with us for a long time in most metropolitan areas, particularly Sydney and Adelaide, and has nothing whatsoever to do with the dynamics of the import parity pricing system.

I should point out that the wholesale price of petrol-in fact, if one takes the national average-has fallen by about 6 per cent in real terms over the last 12 months as a result of the direct flow on of changes in the world oil price scene into the Australian domestic market as a result of that import parity pricing system. One could refer to comparative price increases in petrol over the 10 years of the Liberal Government as compared with our own. Under the Liberal Government, petrol prices rose by 27.5c per litre, from 15.7c per litre to 43.2c per litre over the period that it was in office; whereas prices have risen only from 43.2c per litre to 56.9c per litre, a rise of 13.7c per litre, during our period of office.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —These comparisons, although one is tempted to make them, make no particular sense by virtue of the continued operation of the import parity pricing system under both governments. I cheerfully acknowledge the force of the points that have been made opposite by way of interjection. I am making the point that comparisons of that kind overlook the reality that because, under both governments, our price structure is tied to the world market, there is simply no point in attributing the variations that do occur in market prices to any action that may be taken by government.

ANSWER.PARA: A final point that I think is worth making is that it is quite hypocritical of the Daily Telegraph to point to a petrol price increase of 390 per cent since 1974. This paper is currently sold at 40c. In early 1974 the same paper sold for only 8c, which represents a price increase of 400 per cent over that same period.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In light of the remarks by the Victorian Premier in Melbourne last night supporting the Australian Council of Trade Unions' proposal to limit foreign investment of superannuation funds and suggesting that the Victorian Government will consider ways to achieve this end, does the Minister recall saying in Estimates Committee C on 16 September, in reference to overseas investment by the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust: `What the Trust does is no business of governments'? Can the Minister clear up what is obviously a conflict of ideas between himself, the ACTU and the Cain Government? Will the Minister advise the Senate what action the Commonwealth Government intends to take in regard to the ACTU's proposals?

—In response to the last part of the question, I will see what the Treasurer has to say as to whether he intends to put any submissions to Cabinet in response to Mr Cain, the Australian Council of Trade Unions or anyone else. My words quoted from the Estimates Committee Hansard of 16 September have been-I do not say that it has been done deliberately-taken out of context. They were said in the context that the Government does not direct the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust just because it is an organisation set up by statute and it invests the contributions of Commonwealth employees. It is expected to operate as a commercial organisation but of course all superannuation funds have to operate under more general guidelines or legislation and SFIT, like the fully private funds, has a framework imposed by the Government within which it must operate. I am not forecasting that this would happen or is likely to happen, but should the Government decide to apply any restrictions to superannuation funds in the way in which they can invest their money or how much of it they can invest off-shore, I would expect that type of rule to apply to the SFIT and to the private funds alike.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It was recently announced by the South Australian Attorney-General that legislation to grant Family Court jurisdiction in cases involving the maintenance and custody of so-called illegitimate children will be introduced in South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania. Currently such cases are heard in State courts whilst the Family Court deals with matters involving legitimate children, creating all sorts of confusion and lack of rationalisation of services. Can the Minister say when the Family Court will assume this responsibility and what provisions will be made for Queensland and Western Australia, States which have not yet conferred on the Family Court jurisdiction to deal with all matters of maintenance, guardianship, custody and access to children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that Victoria and South Australia have introduced Bills into their respective State Parliaments to refer to the Commonwealth Parliament legislative powers in relation to the custody, guardianship, maintenance, access and child bearing expenses of all children subject to a proviso to preserve the operation of State child welfare laws. Those Bills are expected to be passed this year. The timetable for the implementation of the powers thus referred remains to be sorted out but I for one hope that it will be done as soon as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: New South Wales and Tasmania are also to introduce similar Bills later this year. The Commonwealth will amend the Family Law Act to confer the additional jurisdiction on the Family Court and courts exercising jurisdiction under that Act according to the timetable yet to be determined, as I said. The big problem remains, as always, Queensland. The Queensland Attorney-General has indicated that the Queensland Government simply does not intend to refer these powers. He sought approval for the establishment of a State family court in Queensland as an alternative. The Commonwealth Attorney-General has rejected-as I did before him, and I think maybe even Senator Durack did before that-this alternative proposal for a whole variety of practical and other reasons. We will continue to negotiate for a reference of powers. In the meantime the very unsatisfactory jurisdictional problems that can arise through the operation of dual systems will continue to operate in respect of ex-nuptial children of that State.

As Western Australia has its own State Family Court, for reasons going back some time in history and which continue to make reasonable sense, it presently exercises jurisdiction in the matters that would be given to the Commonwealth under the reference of powers. So the need for a reference of powers from Western Australia extends only to the provision of uniformity of laws on custody, guardianship and maintenance. I mention finally that in both Western Australia and Queensland the existing arrangements for the hearing of custody, guardianship and maintenance cases for ex-nuptial children will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation to ascertain as a matter of urgency whether the following sequence of events which could amount to a serious misleading of a Senate Estimates Committee by the Department of Aviation took place: Did an officer of the Department of Aviation take on notice questions for Qantas Airways Ltd concerning health warnings on cigarette packets sold on Qantas aircraft? Is it a fact that no answers to these questions were forwarded to the Committee when answers to questions taken on notice by the Department of Aviation were provided? Was a letter from Mr J. F. Moffatt, on behalf of the Department of Aviation, received by the Committee, which stated: `A response to those questions will be forwarded as soon as it becomes available.'? Has the Committee taken Qantas to task in its report tabled in the Senate this morning for not providing answers to these questions in satisfactory time? Is it a fact that this morning Mr Kavanagh, an officer of the Department of Aviation, informed the Secretary of the Estimates Committee orally that the answers to the questions had been provided to Mr Potter of the Department of Aviation about a week ago? I ask that these matters be determined urgently, Mr President, because if they are as suggested there may have been a breach of the privilege of the Senate which I may have to raise for you to determine.

—I recall Senator Peter Baume asking at a meeting of Senate Estimates Committee F for certain information about the practice of Qantas aircraft on overseas flights selling cigarettes on the packets of which the health warnings required for the sale of cigarettes in Australia did not appear. There was concern about the legality of the action Qantas had taken in this respect. This matter was referred by the Department of Aviation to the Attorney-General for interpretation as to whether there was any breach of Commonwealth law. Following my request to Qantas that it expedite the response to the matters raised by Senator Peter Baume, Qantas has now advised me that as cigarettes sold on board its aircraft are for export there is no requirement for cigarette manufacturers to include a health warning on the packets. That is the advice of Qantas to the Government. Notwithstanding that advice, Qantas has arranged with the cigarette manufacturers with which the company deals to provide Qantas with packets that carry a health warning. The company has advised that the health warnings will appear on the packets within three months, because of the time required for modification of the printing format and the acquittal of existing stocks. The Department of Aviation has consulted the Department of Health on this general question, which I gather then sought a legal opinion from the Attorney-General relating to international carriers. The Department of Health has now advised that the situation has been examined against the background of rotational health warnings on tobacco product packages. At this point I doubt that there has been a breach of privilege as suggested by Senator Baume. However, if there is a problem in that area I will examine it and draw it to the attention of the appropriate authorities.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am very grateful to the Minister for the information he has provided but it did not answer my question. My question was, quite simply: Is it a fact that the Department, in a letter forwarded to Estimates Committee F, said that it had no answers to certain questions and is it a fact that the Department today has advised orally that it had held those answers for a week? That is the question, Mr President. I am perfectly prepared to table the letter received by Estimates Committee F.
—Order! The honourable senator has asked his supplementary question.

—I think I indicated that if Senator Peter Baume made that document available I would be prepared to examine it to see whether there was any breach of privilege. If there is, I will take the appropriate steps. I do not have a copy of it, although I am aware of some of its contents. I would certainly seek information from the Department to see whether there has been any intent on the part of any departmental officer to withhold information to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to Press reports that the Premier of Queensland has replied to correspondence regarding the disposition of $3m which had been placed as part of the Commonwealth's commitment to Expo 88. What is the substance of the Queensland Premier's answer? In addition, has the Queensland Premier yet replied to correspondence of 18 and 26 September regarding the Queensland Government's use of Commonwealth funds under the natural disaster relief arrangements? If so, what is the substance of that reply or replies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter which I sent to the Queensland Premier on 14 October, regarding his allegation that the Commonwealth had made no contribution to Expo 88, was answered the next day, which demonstrates that where the Queensland Government has nothing to hide, it is quite capable of answering correspondence very promptly. I am relieved that the Premier has advised me that the $3m is still being held in the trust account where it is supposed to be and is still accruing interest. It has not been siphoned off for some improper use, as has been happening recently in the case of Commonwealth funds paid to Queensland. In the letter he also seized the chance to do a bit of lobbying for additional Commonwealth funding for Expo. Of course, it has always been the case that some additional Commonwealth money would be available. Indeed, a very substantial additional amount would be available. In addition, of course-something the Premier's letter does not address-the Commonwealth Government has paid the operational expenses of the chief organiser of Expo, Mr Justice Williams, who, I understand, is known as Neddy Williams and is a close friend of the Premier. So the Premier ought to be aware of that, too.
—He flies all over the world.
—Is he in the club? I am told that he flies all over the world. The Commonwealth will provide a number of other services when the Expo is held.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the second part of Senator Black's question-that is, what replies have I had to my letters to the Premier of 18 and 26 September regarding Queensland Government administration, or, more accurately, maladministration, of Commonwealth funded national disaster relief arrangements-I also received what purported to be a reply to those letters yesterday. I should say, however, that there was nothing of substance in that letter. It did not address the specific questions that I asked in my letters of 18 and 26 September-that is, whether funds had been used in accordance with the guidelines. He also failed to give any indication of whether any investigation had been carried out into apparent fraudulent practices in relation to NDRA applications. I certainly do not accept statements such as this:
In regard to the specific matter raised in your letter of 18 September 1986 this has been amply and completely discussed in the public arena. There is nothing to add.

The matter referred to, of course, in the letter of 18 September was the $145,000 loan that was provided to the National Party employee and failed Senate candidate, Mr Michael Behan, against the advice and recommendation of the Agricultural Bank and the Rural Reconstruction Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did someone try to knock you off, Ron?

—I think Senator Boswell has told us that he did not get one of those, Senator. It is a bit of a surprise. I think he has told us previously that he did not get one. He must be about the only National Party member in Queensland--
—Order! I ask Senator Walsh to come to the question or to resume his seat.

—Certainly, Mr President. The Queensland Premier, in that reply, has not addressed the issues that I raised, nor has he provided the specific information which I sought, which could readily be provided if the Government had nothing to hide. Finally, I certainly do not intend to let the matter drop.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROTECTION OF MOVABLE CULTURAL HERITAGE LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. In spite of the fact that the protection of movable cultural heritage legislation was passed in the Senate on 13 May 1986, it has not been proclaimed. It has come to my attention that items of unique cultural significance are still being exported, much to the consternation of the Opposition, museum directors and other concerned Australians. In view of this, when does the Minister anticipate that the legislation will be proclaimed so that this drain on our cultural heritage will be stopped-the very thing that the legislation was meant to do?
—I will try to obtain by the end of Question Time an answer to that question in respect of the likely proclamation date.

—Was the attention of the Minister for Finance drawn to an article in the Age of Wednesday, 15 October, entitled `Tax chief opposes a return to old law on perks'? In that article the Commissioner of Taxation, Trevor Boucher, was quoted as saying that those who advocated a return to the former law ignored or forgot history. Mr Boucher also stated that employer collection of the fringe benefits tax was `in fair company with pay as you earn concepts'. Does the Minister agree that a return to the old system of untaxed perks, as the Opposition appears to want, would cost the rest of the taxpaying community hundreds of millions of dollars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I agreed that attempts to tax fringe benefits under section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act would lead to the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars. I do not agree with that, because it would lead to the loss of billions of dollars of revenue. It would have to be measured in billions of dollars. If the fringe benefits tax was to be repealed, as the Opposition says it would be if it came into government, the leakage of revenue would be measured in billions, not hundreds of millions, of dollars.

ANSWER.PARA: The statement that Mr Boucher made-I think it was made three days ago-of course, scuttled whatever credibility the discredited Leader of the Opposition may previously had had, or any credibility that the Opposition substitute for a tax policy may previously have had. The Commissioner of Taxation has stated unequivocally that fringe benefits cannot be taxed effectively under section 26 (e). That was the same judgment that the Government made, of course, and the reason why the Government proceeded with its fringe benefits tax legislation. If, in addition, this Government's fringe benefits tax legislation were to be repealed, it would then become known that there was no tax to be levied on fringe benefits. The floodgates would open and billions of dollars of revenue would be lost from people who could arrange their affairs appropriately. Of course, they would be the sort of people that the Liberal Party represents. They would not be ordinary Australians. Ordinary Australians would be forced to pay more tax in order to plug the gaping hole in the revenue that the actions of a Liberal government would open up.

Mr Howard does not seem to have much luck with tax commissioners, past or present. Mr O'Reilly effectively dumped on him, having regard to the 28 desperate entreaties he wrote to Mr Howard, begging him to stop the bottom of the harbour tax racket. Now the present Commissioner is saying that the substitute for a tax policy which the Opposition is putting up is unworkable. The kindest interpretation one can put on the Opposition's policy particularly that of its Leader, is it is incompetent. The least kind interpretation is that he knows exactly what he is doing-that is, he will facilitate tax evasion if he becomes Prime Minister, just as he did as Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Why are parliamentarians dependent for information on newspaper articles, such as that published in last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald, to learn of the Minister's response to an Australian Academy of Technological Sciences study requested by the Minister for Science on a space policy for Australia? Why was the Madigan report not tabled in Parliament, and why is not a copy readily available from the Parliamentary Library, except on inter-library loan? In view of the reported very attractive cost-benefits ratio of such a government funded space program, why has the Minister apparently rejected out of hand and without parliamentary debate such an opportunity for Australian industry and for future Australian export and import replacement earnings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been two responses to the Government's announcement about the space industry, one of the kind which Senator Vigor implies in his question and the other which I have seen in several journals which really make the point that the program the Government announced is in the right directions and is a sensible one given current fiscal restraints. `Fiscal restraints' is an expression which is not in the dictionary of Senator Vigor's questions asked in this Parliament but it is something which has to concern governments. In some way or other we are all involved in the process of government-and the sooner Senator Vigor learns that, the better for us all.

ANSWER.PARA: Copies of the Madigan report have been available from the Department of Science and my Department. It is not a policy document; it is a report to me, the Minister for Science and the Australian Science and Technology Council. The report to which Senator Vigor referred has not been rejected out of hand; it has been the subject of some 18 months' consideration and consultation between departments, industry and other governments. I thought that we might have been chastised for delay, rather than rejecting it out of hand. Nobody knows whether the investments referred to in the third part of the honourable senator's question pay back their costs. To the best of our knowledge, space programs have been profitable only if government investment in them in various other countries is written off. It is an extraordinary cost-benefit analysis which ignores a large percentage of the costs. There is also the opportunity cost of the Government's investment. Maybe investment in the individual component technologies of space activity, rather than space technology as a whole, would show far greater returns.

The Government's plans for supplying equipment in the 1990s and beyond are in the process of being developed. The Government has established, in response to the Madigan report, an Australian space board, which I think was the subject of a thoughtful question from Senator Archer not so long ago. Senator Archer is not nodding his agreement; he is just nodding off. Recently I announced a strategy for the development of the communications equipment industry, which is interwoven, as it were, with space industry matters. There are a number of initiatives taken by the Government which, when put together, present a very satisfactory and responsible response to the Madigan report, and to the honourable senator's question.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Vigor proceeding to address a supplementary question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is not a supplementary question. It adds additional material and I rule it out of order.

—I remind the Minister representing the Minister for Defence that the Government claims that the so-called joint facilities are good for us because they contribute to deterrence through early warning. I ask: Is it not standard practice in strategic analysis to base conclusions on what others are capable of doing, not on what they say they will do? Is it not a fact that the satellites which provide early warning also provide real time data on the status of the Soviet intercontinental ballistic missile force, data necessary for fighting a nuclear war? Can the Minister explain on what basis the Government accepts United States assurances that it does not want to fight a nuclear war, while maintaining in this country facilities which add to the American capability to fight such a war? Is it just that the Government trusts United States assurances or has it something more solid to rely on? If so, what?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine will not expect me to confirm her speculation about the roles and functions of the joint facilities beyond referring her to the Prime Minister's statement of 6 June 1984, which statement, she will recall, says in part that among the functions performed by the joint facilities is the provision of early warning about missile launches. As to the merits of that early warning capacity, which is the nub of the honourable senator's question, I have to say to her-and I hope she forgives me for the robustness with which I say it-that no sane strategic analyst doubts that the better the early warning available, the less likely a nuclear war is to start. By significantly enhancing the early warning available to the United States our facilities do make a major contribution to preventing nuclear war. Senator Vallentine's concern about the possibility that these capabilities might be used during a nuclear war, should one ever happen, has to be balanced against the certainty that they are being used, right now and every day, to prevent nuclear war occurring.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vallentine asked, finally, on what basis we accept United States assurances that it does not wish to fight a nuclear war. We accept those assurances because we know that whatever particular difficulties we as a country might have with particular aspects of United States policy-conspicuously the strategic defence initiative-we do know that the United States believes, as I know Senator Vallentine believes, that a nuclear war would be a global tragedy of unimaginable proportions-with one estimate of the casualties in the United States alone being 140 million people. The Government finds that fact alone a very solid basis for believing that President Reagan means what he says when he says that a nuclear war must never be fought and can never be won.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has trotted out the usual inadequate line about the bases' role in monitoring and verification. How on earth does he explain that when most of the agreements which these bases are meant to monitor and verify were actually put in place after the bases were established?

—There is a spectacular logic tangle there somewhere, but I do not think it has been perpetrated by the Government. The difficulty is to answer the question with any precision without going into rather more precision about what precisely the bases do. In general terms, I can simply say that early warning and verification are the functions. Early warning is a concept that pre-exists any particular agreement, but verification exists as a concept whatever the particular arms control agreement might be that the bases are helping us to verify.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have noted the recent statement of the Minister for Resources and Energy regarding revenue sharing arrangements for Bass Strait petroleum. I ask: What is the present position of the Victorian Government regarding the foreshadowed action in the High Court of Australia to have the Commonwealth excise disallowed as a deduction from selling prices before the royalty is calculated as a percentage of the net well-head value? Has the Victorian Government advised the Minister of the basis of its proposed action in the High Court or is it likely that this proposed case will be abandoned by the Victorian Government?
—It is only going to make a few more lawyers rich.

—I cannot help but agree with Senator Walsh that the only people this action will benefit will be some of the legal profession. The matter that is upsetting Victoria about the mode of calculation of royalty and whether it should be done in such a way that it gets a higher dollar return than is the case under present interpretation of the agreement has been pursued on and off by Victoria over a number of years and during successive governments, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will no doubt recall. The position that has been adopted consistently by Commonwealth governments is that the language of the agreement, which goes back to the late 1960s, is unequivocally clear: There is no basis for anything other than an emotive argument about the revenue sharing arrangements. Certainly there is no possibility that we can see, with the benefit of all the legal advice available to us-which I have personally scrutinised, for what that is worth-that a challenge to those arrangements through the courts could possibly succeed. It is an old chestnut which has been brought out and dusted off. Whether it will be pursued with any great vigour by Victoria remains to be seen. But it is certainly a course of action which will be vigorously resisted by the Commonwealth.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the substantial devaluation of the Australian dollar in recent months and the Government's desire to boost manufacturing exports. Does the devaluation suggest that the Royal Australian Mint, a public sector manufacturing authority, now has greater potential to win contracts to produce coins for other countries? If so, will the Government take the necessary steps to enable the Mint to take advantage of this new-found competitiveness?

—The Mint is currently producing coins for Tonga and the Cook Islands and has just finished a run of coins for Fiji. I was a bit surprised to learn recently that Canada is presently producing New Zealand's coins and that Papua New Guinea may have had coins minted in the United Kingdom or in Canada. If I remember correctly, normally the Australian Mint has produced coins for New Zealand. Obviously the devaluation has made the Mint vastly more competitive than it would otherwise have been and it ought, therefore, to be well placed to obtain further contracts from other countries. I will ask the Treasurer to investigate the possibility and probably report on just what efforts the Mint is making.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I hope the Minister recalls that on Tuesday I asked him the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Government ask the Commissioner of Taxation for a detailed report on the likely impact of the fringe benefits tax, including specific problems likely to arise, before the tax became law? If so, did the Commissioner identify any of the unintended consequences that have now caused the Prime Minister to order a review of the tax? If he did, why did the Government proceed with such obviously defective legislation?
Can the Minister representing the Treasurer now answer the question?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to recall what I said on Tuesday, but I think I said that I did not know whether the Commissioner of Taxation had prepared a report of that type or not and that I would see whether the Treasurer had one to supply to Senator Hamer. I am afraid that one has not been supplied to me yet, but I will remind the Treasurer again.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is not in fact what the Minister said. The Minister said that he did not know and, as far as I could gather, he did not care. But is the Minister saying, in view of the problems that the FBT has created, that he has not bothered to inquire whether the Taxation Commissioner was consulted? If the Taxation Commissioner was not consulted before the new tax was introduced, why was he not consulted?

—Mr President, I am no more responsible for taxation policy than I suppose any other member of the Cabinet. I have no responsibility at all for taxation administration. That is the job of the Treasurer.
—You are representing the Treasurer.

—It is true that I have responsibility for answering such questions here. I have already said that I will see, firstly, whether the Treasurer does have such a report and, secondly, if he does, whether he is willing to make it available. I think the answer to the second part would be no, but I cannot say that for certain.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Are the recently discussed proposals to limit smoking in Public Service offices to be extended to the Commonwealth drivers' work environment, namely, Commonwealth cars?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most honourable senators would recognise that I have very strong views about smoking. Of course, there is a measure of support in this chamber for looking after the rights of non-smokers. The Government has, through the Public Service Board, established criteria for smoking in Commonwealth offices. ANSWER.PARA: Public servants are required to comply with non-smoking initiatives in their work place and comparable initiatives in car fleets would require that drivers take responsibility for enforcement if we were to apply that principle to Commonwealth cars. TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) relating to counter terrorism in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The Government has recently completed a review of counter-terrorism capabilities in Australia and of the administrative and financial arrangements which support them.

The Government initiated this review in December 1985. It was then some six years after the report of Mr Justice Hope had established the current arrangements and in the light of the upsurge of terrorism in Europe and the Middle East during 1984 and 1985 it was timely to review Australia's arrangements.
The events of 1986 have confirmed the timeliness of the review.

The review was carried out by my Department in consultation with other appropriate departments. As part of the review, I made a visit in June to Italy, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Japan, where I had discussions on counter-terrorism with relevant Ministers, and with police and security agencies. I was also briefed in detail on airport security arrangements in those countries.
THE TERRORIST THREAT TO AUSTRALIA

Australia is fortunate in not having disaffected domestic political or separatist groups who resort to terrorism, such as have many countries in Western Europe. We are also geographically distant from the main centres of international terrorism.
We have not entirely escaped terrorism. Major incidents in the past include:
the murder of the Turkish Consul-General and his bodyguard;
the bombings of the Israeli Consulate-General and the Hakoah Club;
the wounding of the Indian Defence Attache and the kidnapping of the attache and his wife.

Nor should we be complacent about the future. It is important, however, that we not lose a sense of proportion and base our arrangements for counter-terrorism on worst-case scenarios; rather we need to make a sober and rational assessment of the threat. It is here that Australia's intelligence agencies and our links to international agencies play a vital role.

Even though Australians have been the innocent victims of incidents overseas and in this country, the present assessment is that there is currently no evidence to indicate that Australia is a chosen target of any international terrorist group. It needs to be borne in mind that Australia has close historical and political ties with a number of nations which are under high terrorist threat and which have substantial interests in this country. These interests may well be seen as attractive targets by terrorist groups.

The threat of terrorist attacks against targets in Australia is assessed by ASIO as low now and in the foreseeable future. This low threat is international in character, although we must face the possibility that some overseas terrorist groups may have a very few supporters in this country.
Bombings and assassinations are the methods of attack currently preferred by terrorists and I am advised that this is likely to apply to any attacks which may be carried out in Australia.

The Government recognises that the source and the nature of the threat can change rapidly, but it accepts the advice that the current low level of threat against targets in Australia and the likely international emphasis on bombings and assassinations can generally be expected to persist for a period. The Government will therefore ensure that preventive and contingency measures against terrorism give the highest priority to these most likely forms of threat.
CONCLUSIONS OF THE REVIEW
I now wish to inform the House of the findings of the review and the Government's response.

Acting on advice from the Secretaries' Committee on Intelligence and Security, the Government will not be publishing the report of the review. A complete copy has been made available to the Leader of the Opposition and a version with only minor editing will be made available to the States.

In general terms, the review concludes that an effective national counter-terrorist capability has been established in Australia. This follows the creation of the Standing Advisory Committee for Commonwealth-State Co-operation on Protection Against Violence, known as SAC-PAV, in 1979.
The picture today is vastly different to 1979. There is an atmosphere of co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States that could not have been foreseen seven years ago.

Through SAC-PAV, the Commonwealth has provided the States with compatible equipment and helped to develop among them similar levels of expertise. The relevant Commonwealth authorities can now interact with each State more easily, and are more likely to be invited to do so. The State governments and police forces can also more readily interact. Extensive crisis management machinery has been developed that can be activated in response to a terrorist incident anywhere in Australia.

A highly skilled and well-equipped counter-terrorism force has been established within the Defence Force to respond, as a measure of last resort, to requests to resolve terrorist incidents by force. Every State now possesses a capability to cope with siege-hostage incidents, at least those of relatively short duration. All States have a raised capacity to deal with bombings.
PREVENTIVE MEASURES

The review emphasised that the single most important preventive measure against terrorism is the capability to produce timely and accurate intelligence. The Commonwealth's principal agency for gathering and evaluating security intelligence is ASIO. That Organisation's particular role was, of course, thoroughly examined by the recent Royal Commission conducted by Mr Justice Hope.

Co-operation between intelligence and law enforcement agencies, both in Australia and internationally, is vital in the area of counter-terrorism. This was a point strongly emphasised to me by all concerned during my overseas visit. The review reported general satisfaction with co-operation between the agencies in Australia.

Relative to many other nations, Australia has a greater capacity to prevent known or suspected foreign terrorists from entering this country. The review emphasised the importance of the security-checking mechanisms now in place with several foreign security services which could provide information on the movement of terrorists in time to prevent their entry into Australia. The Government accepts the importance of these mechanisms.
The review further recommended that current entry control procedures be maintained, including the necessity for visitors to Australia to obtain visas.
These recommendations will be taken into account by the Government in any future examination of this issue.

The review drew attention to the need to enhance the protection of Commonwealth explosives and weapons and to make a careful assessment of the threat posed by other sources of dangerous materials of potential use to terrorists. As a result of the review, action is being taken to upgrade our performance in this area.
PROTECTIVE MEASURES

The protection of potential targets is a vital measure in any country's fight against terrorism. This is an area of change in the Commonwealth as a number of the former protective roles of the Australian Federal Police have passed to the Australian Protective Service. The Government sees the advantage to both the development of the AFP and to the performance of protective functions in this change.
There are Commonwealth-State arrangements for the protection of holders of high office in Australia or dignitaries who may be visiting Australia.

The very considerable resources and the degree of co-ordination required have been recently demonstrated in the visit by the Indian Prime Minister. The forthcoming visit of the Pope will also be a major exercise.

While this task must remain primarily the function of the particular State police forces the review has pointed to the need for agreement on minimum standards of protection in response to different levels of threat.
This will be pursued in the SAC-PAV forum.
REACTIVE MEASURES

Australia needs to be prepared to respond if preventive measures fail and a terrorist incident takes place. A major element of Australia's response to incidents of terrorism is a policy of no concessions, other than tactical ones, to terrorist demands. That policy has been considered and re-endorsed by the Government as a result of the review.

The review pointed to the need for some improvement in the information flow to Commonwealth Ministers during a terrorist incident to enable them to make any necessary policy decisions. This need has emerged during a number of Commonwealth-State joint exercises. The review also pointed to the need to plan and train for post incident investigations and other actions which would form a major part of the response to a `hit and run' incident, such as an assassination or a bombing, if we are to improve the chance of apprehending offenders and hence reduce terrorism. The Commonwealth will be looking to the SAC-PAV to extend its exercise program to test arrangements for Australia's response to this wider range of incidents.

There may be terrorist incidents arising overseas in which Australian interests would be heavily involved and in which Australia could be called upon to assist. The Government is examining the complex issues raised by such situations.
AVIATION SECURITY

It is clear from international experience that airports and aviation, particularly international aviation, are prime targets for terrorist attack. On my visit to Europe I was struck by the very particular attention being paid to high risk flights at major European airports. The flights of certain airlines and flights to and from certain destinations are given very special attention; otherwise more routine precautions prevail.

Fortunately, the terrorist threat to aviation in Australia is assessed as low. Our aviation security arrangements fully meet all of the ICAO standards. Nonetheless, it is important that we keep the security needs of our airports under constant review so that we can ensure that we are prepared to face any problem which may arise.

In the light of the review's recommendations, bomb and weapon search procedures are being reviewed to ensure that these continue to be adequate for the prevailing circumstances. The current system of issuing passes to people for access to security areas of airports is also being looked at to see what strengthening might be desirable.

The Government is also concerned with the broader aspects of physical security measures at airports and is taking action to improve current arrangements. My Department and the Department of Aviation have established a joint task force on proposals to improve aviation security at all Australian airports.

The difficult question of policing of airports was addressed in the review. At present, uniformed Australian Federal Police are present at Australian airports. Their role in a terrorist incident would be one of containment until the arrival of State police. Inevitably, as a visible presence, they are called upon to undertake something of a community policing role, which properly belongs to State forces.

There has been criticism of the numbers of AFP members at airports for counter-terrorism purposes. This criticism is not supported by the AFP on the basis of the present threat and current national planning for a counter-terrorist response. It is also worth mentioning that the AFP has other roles and often considerable resources at airports working in intelligence, drugs and other operations.

The review canvassed the options of a special airport branch of the AFP but favoured rather the transfer of the counter-terrorism protective function to the States. This was seen as better, meeting any possible problems of two forces in one incident and offering greater flexibility should the threat increase.
I will be discussing this possibility with the AFP, the Australian Federal Police Association and the States and will then bring forward a further submission to the Government.
BOMBING INCIDENTS

Bombings have been the most common type of terrorist incident in Australia and are expected to be the most likely form of such incidents in the future. While bombings are assessed as the major threat from terrorists, the Government is concerned that this should be reflected in the attention given to the subject by the SAC-PAV and in the allocation of money to the SAC-PAV by the Commonwealth.

Provision has been made in 1986-87 to expend $350,000 on bomb disposal and related equipment. We are planning next year-1987-88-to spend the entire SAC-PAV plant and equipment vote on equipment that will further enhance our anti-bombing capacity.
The review highlighted, among other things, the absence of SAC-PAV exercises aimed at testing bomb response capabilities.

As a direct consequence of this finding, a bomb response seminar is to be held in Canberra on 5 November 1986. The seminar, to be attended by Australian and overseas experts in forensic science, counter-terrorism and explosives, will examine Australia's preparedness to respond to world-wide trends in the use of explosives by terrorists.

In addition, the SAC-PAV has been asked to develop a bomb response strategy for the next three to five years with the emphasis on equipment, training and personnel requirements. This proposal will be discussed further by the bomb response seminar and the 16th meeting of the SAC-PAV in November 1986.
FINANCIAL ARRANGEMENTS

Finally, there was an examination of the financial arrangements as between the Commonwealth and States. Since 1980-81 the Commonwealth has spent about $10m on equipment, ammunition and training through SAC-PAV. Annual costs for counter-terrorism aspects of ASIO, the Defence Force, the AFP and my Department amount to about $30m.

A variety of alternative options was considered, including a `user pays' principle, a fixed Commonwealth-State contribution ratio and a Commonwealth-only option. The mechanisms necessary to control the financial contributions made by the Commonwealth through the SAC-PAV towards the national capability was canvassed.

The review concluded that the present financial guidelines, with some minor administrative adjustments, should be maintained. The Government accepts that recommendation and will continue to provide financial support through SAC-PAV within modified guidelines.
CONCLUSION

The Commonwealth will seek the continued co-operation of the States and the Northern Territory in putting into effect measures arising out of the review. The Prime Minister is writing to the premiers and the Chief Minister following the review. The Government acknowledges the excellent level of co-operation which has already been achieved.

Terrorism, by its very nature, recognises neither geographic nor political boundaries. Although the threat is currently assessed as low, there will be no reduction in our vigilance nor in the maintenance of the national capability.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —National security cannot be compromised, and whether this is by armed forces, organised terrorists or individual fanatics, the nation must have the capacity to respond both effectively and quickly. There has to be an adequate deterrent element as well, and this report covers these aspects. May I say, first, that I have been most impressed by the capabilities and preparedness of the Special Advisory Committee for the Protection Against Violence and its chief, Mr MacKenzie-Orr. I have participated in one of its exercises and I suggest that if anyone with terrorist sympathies is listening he ought to think twice before he proceeds.

SPEECH.PARA: The report, as a progress and reassessment report, was necessary and I believe that the statement made by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) clarifies the matters of importance and the various issues that are under consideration. There is the general view at large that Australia has a minimum risk factor. I hope that this is so, but I would not want us all to fall into the trap of believing that we have no potential problem. We have, and we do need to keep it under constant re-appraisal. As yet we believe that we are not a chosen target, but we cannot say that that will always be so. Bombings and assassinations can occur and we have to be ready to act.

The job that SAC-PAV has done to co-ordinate the efforts of all the interests involved in terrorism is excellent. It has come a long way but still needs to look forward to the next eventuality or possibility. The provision of comparable equipment, for instance, has helped the co-ordination considerably, and its general standard of preparedness is excellent. We certainly now have a highly motivated, skilled and well equipped anti-terrorist force in Australia, but I hope we may never need to see it in action. Intelligence-the work done primarily in Australia by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-is also critical, as is the co-operation between it and the police forces. The arrangements that have been made between the Commonwealth and State authorities in all these areas also have been improved tremendously. In 1979 Mr Justice Hope said:
The first line of defence against terrorism is intelligence.

How true that is. Our intelligence forces, as a result, must be right up to the mark, and the Government must stifle any efforts, whether from within the Australian Labor Party or from outside, that would impair or frustrate the efficiency of ASIO in any way. We have a great and natural capacity for some protection both by our location in the southern hemisphere and by our geographical separation from other countries. I say `some protection', but we must make it as secure as we can, and secure all the time. We need to keep our policy of no concessions fully understood. In itself it is a sound protective measure, even taking into account all that it implies.

Airport security is carefully reported in the statement. Over the past few years there have been many comments made about the degree to which we have adequate airport security. It is often said that airport security is unco-ordinated and inadequate and this is regularly debated by the people involved. Amongst the issues raised in the report on the subject are the access of visitors to departure lounges, the more careful screening of all people with regular airport access, and care that airlines with doubtful reputations are not admitted to our airports. We need to bear all this in mind when having regard to the fact that over the last 10 years the number of visitors to Australia has more than doubled. We do not wish to see our system of granting visas in any way watered down. It is very important that we have adequate notice of who is coming to Australia and that we are able to check on them as they come in. I would not wish to see anything happen that would weaken this system.

The policing of our 12 international airports is still not determined, and to say that another round of discussions will be held is barely adequate. I hope that the Government not only discusses this but gets on and makes the changes that are necessary. We must take into account the fact that there could be elements of a fifth column in Australia that could actually support terrorist regimes and which may show succour to their adherents and operatives. Similarly we cannot ignore the possibility that persons involved in organised crime may indulge in extreme actions at some stage. there is absolutely no room for complacency. I am pleased to see the Minister's statement, but it is not the statement that is important; the important thing is how the Government goes about taking action on how long that will take. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill contains amendments to Social Security and Veterans' Affairs legislation to implement decisions affecting those portfolios in the 1986-87 Budget. Honourable senators will be aware that, as a result of international economic conditions, there have been significant reductions in Australia's national income. The Government believes that through the Budget and other policy changes, the problems which this creates can be faced squarely and remedial changes put in place quickly and decisively. These changes must be made so that our domestic economy and standard of living can be adjusted to our current circumstances. The Budget therefore incorporates very large reductions in spending, amongst other measures.

In making difficult decisions, the Government has sought to ensure that the burden of change is spread as fairly as possible across the community, while maintaining the Labor Party's traditional commitment to the needy. Overall, there are reductions against forward estimates of some $500m in social security.

This restraint was achieved with no discounting of indexed rises in pensions and benefits. Within a very constrained budgetary framework, we have been able to steer spending towards some areas of greatest need. And we have continued to tighten administrative procedures in ways that add to the integrity of our programs. Most important of all, nothing in this Budget jeopardises our continuing review and reform of the income security system.
Two major decisions included in the Bill which will affect the Social Security Act 1947 are-
future six monthly indexation increases to pensioners and beneficiaries will continue to be paid in full, but will be deferred for six weeks, i.e. three pension pay-days, from November 1986; and
the measures implemented last year to reduce `poverty traps' in the social security system will be delayed by eight months, until July 1987.

The deferral of indexation increases is estimated to save $129.2m in 1986-87 and $111.4m in 1987-88, and the deferral of the `poverty traps' legislation is estimated to save $126.6m in 1986-87 and $196.5m in 1987-88. These are the only changes to the general pension and benefits area. They do not represent major structural change, and involve minimal disadvantage for those in greatest need. In line with the Government's aim to target welfare payments to the most needy, family allowance for student children between 16 and 18 years of age will be income tested. Families with household income-that is, combined husband and wife taxable incomes-over $39,000 will not be eligible for family allowance. Estimated savings from this measure are $20m in 1986-87 and $49m in 1987-88.
The Government has also decided to increase some payments in areas which will assist the most needy, particularly young families-
additional pension or benefit applicable for a dependent child of a pensioner or beneficiary will be increased by $1 to $17 per week, from November 1986;
the rate of double orphan's pension will be increased by $4.30 to $60 per month, from November 1986;
The rate of handicapped child's allowance will be increased by $7 to $92 per month, from November 1986; and
the rate of mobility allowance would be increased by $1 to $11 per week, from November 1986.
Estimated costs from these four measures are-
increase in additional pension or benefit by $1 per week: $28.3m in 1986-87, and $44.7m in 1987-88;
increase in double orphan's pension by $4.30 per month: $0.2m in 1986-87, and $0.3m in 1987-88;
increase in handicapped child's allowance by $7 per month: $1.7m in 1986-87, and $2.7m in 1987-88; and
increase in mobility allowance by $1 per week: $0.4m in 1986-87, and $0.6m in 1987-88.
Other decisions reflected in the Bill which will further rationalise the social security system are-

the current arrangements by which sickness benefit is either reduced or recovered by reference to compensation payable to the beneficiary will be extended to invalid pension, unemployment benefit, rehabilitation allowance and sheltered employment allowance, from May 1987;
the level of rent payable for a person to be eligible for rent assistance would be increased from $10 to $15 per week, from December 1986;
dual eligibility for both a social security pension or benefit and a war or defence widow's pension would be restructured, from November 1986; and
dual eligibility for both a social security pension and Commonwealth educational scheme payment would be removed, other than for current cases, from January 1987.
estimated savings from these four measures are-

extension of the current arrangements concerning compensation payments: $21m in 1986-87, and $50m in 1987-88-in conjunction with savings from the inclusion of the `appointment formula' in the current sickness benefit arrangements from July 1986;
increase in the rent threshold: $8.8m in 1986-87, and $16.1m in 1987-88;
removal or reduction of dual eligibility for both a social security pension or benefit and a war or defence widow's pension: $4.1m in 1986-87, and $35.1m in 1987-88; and
removal of dual eligibility for both a social security pension and an educational scheme payment-savings in the Education portfolio.

The Government has announced a range of measures to tighten the administration of unemployment benefits and so ensure greater fairness in the allocation of limited funds. We are also introducing new arrangements which will improve the administration of widow's pension and supporting parent's benefit. These arrangements are designed both to assist these pensioners and beneficiaries and to ensure that the correct entitlement is paid.
In the area of unemployment benefit, the Bill will include amendments by which-
unemployment beneficiaries will have to be registered with the CES to qualify for benefit, as from November 1986;
beneficiaries will have to lodge their first income statements and applications for continuation of unemployment benefit in person, as from 1 November 1986; and
arrangements will be made for beneficiaries aged over 55 years who have been receiving social security payment for a year to have relaxed reporting requirements.

Estimated savings from these measures, and other measures not requiring legislation, are $33.9m in 1986-87, and $133.4m in 1987-88. In addition to these measures, youth income proposals announced in the 1985-86 Budget are included in the Bill. The Bill will also amend the definition of `income' which applies in the pension and benefit income tests. The amendment would make it clear that the income test does not create an artificial distinction between capital and income. This development would be inconsistent with the long-standing philosophical approach to the scope of the income test, and would have substantial cost implications, apart from unduly distorting the flow of funds into particular types of investments. The amendment is designed to maintain the current approach to the income test, which will be administered in the same way as it has been in the past. Finally, within the social security area, the Bill will amend the assets test in a number of respects to correct deficiencies found after review. These changes are, as a package, revenue neutral.

This Bill also makes some minor amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911. The amendments would prevent the application of those Acts to employees of the Northern Territory Government and its statutory authorities, and to seamen working in the territorial waters of the Territory. These persons will, from the commencement of the amendments, be covered by a proposed Work Health Act of the Northern Territory.

There are small savings from this change in arrangements. This Bill would also make a number of amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to give effect to the Government's decisions announced in the Budget. The opportunity is also taken in this Bill to make a number of machinery amendments, the need for which has become apparent from the experience of the last four months since the Veterans' Entitlements Act came into operation. The Bill would, in unison with amendments to the Social Security Act 1947, defer for three pension pay days the payment of increased rates of pensions and allowances which are subject to indexation in accordance with movements in the Consumer Price Index. Indexation of income and property value limits for the purpose of the income and assets test will also be deferred. This proposal would lead to savings of $26.6m in 1986-87 and $23.3m in 1987-88.

The Bill would also provide that the rate of service pension payable to a widow who is also in receipt of a war widow's pension, currently payable at $228.20 per fortnight, would be frozen at the rate payable on 1 November 1986. Where service pension is granted to such a war widow at a later date the maximum rate of pension payable would be $120.10 per fortnight.

The other main proposal relates to an option to recover from health benefits funds that amount of fund benefit that would have been payable to their contributors who are treated without charge at the expense of the Repatriation Commission. It is emphasised that this arrangement is entirely voluntary on the part of entitled beneficiaries. This proposal would save an estimated $7.2m in 1986-87 and an estimated $10m in 1987-88.

Other amendments of a budgetary nature include increases in the rates of certain allowances and pensions. The rates of pension payable to orphans of deceased veterans are to be increased; the rate of additional pension payable to veterans suffering from certain incapacities will be increased, as will the rates of attendant allowance and the rates of clothing allowance. Other amendments are to align the assets and income test provisions with those proposed to be made to the Social Security Act 1947. Similar amendments are also made to the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 where appropriate. Finally, the Bill will include savings provisions to ensure that rights to seek reviews of certain decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are preserved and transitional provisions to ensure that money due to the pensioner but unpaid at the death of a pensioner before the commencement of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 may be disbursed under that Act.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned for lunch I was pointing out some of the changes that have occurred in the health service facilities in this country, and that despite a 25 per cent increase in the Medicare levy in this Budget one will see that the present day rate is very bad indeed compared with when it was introduced in February 1974. SPEECH.PARA: In the time remaining to me I will address some of this Government's economic policies; what is wrong with those policies and where we ought to be going in this country. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) earlier this week said in another place that the economic changes were falling into place for the Hawke Government like apples into a slot machine.

He was nudged out of first place at the last moment by the Finance Minister of Egypt. It is a tremendous indictment not only of the Treasurer but also of this Government. Australia has fallen in its ranking and reputation in the economic world over the last two years.

The Treasurer has been very deliberately, blatantly, and dangerously trying to talk up the economy in recent days. He quoted from the report by Moody's Investor Services Inc. the other day in the other place which is supposed to relate to Australia's performance. He quoted very selectively. For example, he neglected to quote from some of the key parts of the report, those parts which point out the continuing high inflation rate, unemployment increases and current account imbalances in 1986-87. All three key statistics for inflation, unemployment, and the current account are continuing to deteriorate. He failed to point out the failure of the Government to tackle the structural rigidities in our economy. He failed to point out that real interest rates in Australia are at their highest level and they are well on the way to being the highest in the Western world. He failed to point out that the economy is slowing in its rate of growth very sharply. He failed to point out that the escalating debt service charges on our balance of payments will cancel out a large part of any trade gains from the depreciation of the Australian dollar. He failed to point out that the flow of long term funds into Australia is likely to slow as investors show a wariness about Australia's external debt.

The reasons for our economic problems are manifest.
