There is no denying that a real reduction in spending by the public sector is an absolute precondition for the improvement of our economic situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the evidence for that?

—The Government of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has said precisely that but it then fails completely to deliver. The reason it fails to deliver is that there are members of the Government such as the Minister who think that the world can be made a better place by governments spending more and more of the taxpayers' money. The Minister is one of the members of the team in the Government that is causing that to happen. That is why this economy continues to deteriorate. That is why when the Government comes to expenditure constraint it has to hit people in our community who are least able to support and defend themselves. That is why the Government has to weasel its way around on spending cuts and delay increases in the allowable earnings of pensioners by deferring the consumer price index increase.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the Government is doing such things is that it does not have the intestinal fortitude to take the difficult decisions required to get a permanent, lasting and meaningful reduction in Government spending. That is the sine qua non of the Government's problem. The delay in the payment of the CPI increase is the reason why members of parliament-I guess this applies to all of us-receive very heart-moving, sincere and genuine protests from movements and representatives of pensioners around this country about the dreadful treatment that the Minister and his Government are meting out. That is the basic problem. The other problems all stem from that. The Government gives no encouragement whatsoever to productive investment in Australia or the free flow of two-way investment. Members of the Minister's Party, such as the Victorian Premier, make outrageous statements, as they did last night in attacking the superannuation fund industry because it has the hide to try to get the best deal for its contributors by investing funds where it can get the best return-and that best return is from investing overseas.

Why is that return better overseas? It is better because of the incompetence of the Government running this country, a government which has forced the return on investment down in such a way that funds are forced to go overseas to earn a reasonable return. It is absolutely disgraceful for the Premier of Victoria to blame superannuation fund managers for acting in the interests of their contributors and for the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) at Question Time today to have the hide to accuse the superannuation fund managers of a lack of moral responsibility when the moral irresponsibility has arisen from the policies of this Labor, socialist, high spending, high taxing and record high interest rate Government. That is from where our problems all stem. There has been a disgraceful and hypocritical performance by members of the Australian Labor Party.

We need a reduction in the total tax burden. If we want business to produce and invest, if we want better returns on investment, we have to get a proper investment climate. What do those opposite do? They up the company rate of tax by 7 per cent to, I think a record level. They impose a whole range of anti-business, anti- investment, anti-employment and anti-growth taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the swinging increases of taxation across the board. These all stem from the fact that the Government does not have the ability, responsibility or competence to be able to put its house in order. People have woken up to the problems that those opposite have caused this country. It shows in the polls. These are the issues we are facing and the problems that the Government is not tackling. These are the reasons why the Australian people will throw out this incompetent Government at the earliest possible opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I will address most of my remarks to the Medicare Levy Bill 1986, which will increase the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent from 1 December 1986. This represents the breaking of an election promise by the Government. That forms the basis of the Australian Democrats' opposition to the Bill. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his Budget Speech, excused this broken promise by saying that, even with the savings from health spending cuts of $300m, rising costs will mean that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Medicare levy should be increased so that it makes a greater contribution to health costs and so that Medicare is self-financing.

Of course, this is an exaggerated claim. Medicare does not and cannot pay for itself. However, broken promises, Budget pressures and economic crises aside, the escalating cost of the provision of health care must be of concern to all people. It certainly is to the Australian Democrats, particularly because we support a universal system of health care which now comes under threat in the face of these cost increases, the rise in the levy and the pressures on the provision of services.

Health care is big business. Expenditure on health services accounts for about $15.5 billion per annum, consuming 7 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product. These costs are rising, not only as a proportion of the GDP but also at a higher rate than the overall consumer price index. In this Budget the Government has certainly moved to try to rein in its spending on direct health care and to reduce the burden on the public purse in several ways, including this proposed increase in the Medicare levy, as well as by a range of funding cuts. But the cuts simply mean that the cost of the care must be borne elsewhere rather than by the Federal Government. There will not necessarily be any reduction in demand or any rationalisation of the administration of services.

As an example, the abolition of the bed-day subsidy to private hospitals simply means that there will be an ongoing effect of increasing private hospital costs. Consequently there will be health insurance premium rises and rises in out of pocket expenses-or both. A further consequence with the decline in the numbers of people taking out private insurance will be increased demand on the public hospital system, which is administered at State level. This move will result in no genuine cost reduction, simply a transferring of the problem, responsibility and blame away from the Federal Government and on to State governments. Clearly there will be no gain for anyone. Increasing levies and cutting costs is really no answer nor would be the dismantling of Medicare, which might be the answer we would receive from the so-called alternative Government.

The community wants a universal basic health insurance scheme aimed at ensuring access to health care for all, regardless of the ability to pay. The Australian Democrats certainly want such a system. We know that the Opposition would toss it out if it came to government, leaving us with a system in which only those who can pay can afford to get sick. That is no alternative. To reduce escalating health care costs we need a genuine and effective emphasis on preventative health care measures to replace the crisis intervention illness-based system. Health care currently is a misnomer. As well, we need to develop systems of payment and treatment which will encourage the efficient and effective use of health services and discourage overuse and misuse. On that first point, preventative health measures, last week we received the report of the Better Health Commission, entitled, `Looking Forward to Better Health'. In the Budget context, we all need to be able to look forward to better health. Many fundamental issues are raised in the report. The report makes any number of useful recommendations which should be followed. I certainly hope that this report will not be another of the valuable reports which come down to Government and Parliament and which are not followed up as they deserve to be.

I draw attention to chapter 1.5 of the report, entitled `Social Impediments to Health Promotion'. If we are to look at genuinely reducing health care costs and talk about health rather than illness, we must bear many aspects in mind. Not the least of these aspects is recognising that, as the report says, `helpful choices are not necessarily equally easy for all members of the community to take'. Personal habits are not always a matter entirely of free choice. People's behaviours are influenced, as the report says, by the behaviour of friends and acquaintances, advertising, what is available in the community in the way of amenities and people's values and beliefs and those of the society as a whole. They are also influenced by personal knowledge, priorities and disposable income. I take an example directly from the report. If a senior executive in commerce or industry chooses to spend an hour twice a week in a gymnasium or jogging, it can be accomplished by a rearrangement of time and the expenditure of part of that person's disposable income. Such a health activity is virtually impossible for a single mother who is looking after two children.

TALK.START.PARA: —She would get plenty of exercise anyway.

—Yes, but it would not always necessarily be healthy. That brings me to the other aspect of personal choices, the stresses involved in life-styles and the ability to change life-styles which is dependent, again, on many other aspects of social policy. We cannot avoid these things if we are genuinely to look at reducing health costs. It is already evident that many people in the community, such as that senior executive, perhaps, are making different choices. They should be encouraged. It is quite evident that people's dietary habits are changing. There is a rush on the health food stores. People-such as our senior executive, almost legendary by now-are taking more exercise and generally thinking about what constitutes health. Community expectations are changing and so are our behaviours. Another fundamental problem is pointed out in the Better Health Commission's report. This a matter of great concern. I quote the report:

SPEECH.PARA: Doctors in Australia are paid to react to, not to prevent, disease.

I would go further and say that doctors in Australia are trained to react to and not to prevent diseases. The Australian Democrats' health policy emphasises the need to broaden the training and education of health professionals to include nutrition, contraception, psychology, rehabilitation, family dynamics, human development and so on. It is important that entrance to medical courses should be based on an interview assessment of personality and commitment as well as academic ability in order that this barrier can be overcome. However, even in the event that there is-and there very often is-a recognition by a medical practitioner of the importance of prevention, there is yet another impediment, as the report identifies in chapter 4 entitled `Using Financial Incentives for Better Health'. The problem is that under the system which currently operates there is no financial recompense for medical practitioners who wish to engage with their patients in this kind of preventive exercise. Some of the detail in the report is extremely interesting. The report accepts the fact that many practitioners want to engage in this sort of activity. On the basis of its surveys of the profession it suggests that it was encouraged by the fact that many practitioners see health promotion as part of their role.

The Royal Australian College of Practitioners, in a recent survey, found that 70 per cent of general practitioners agreed that over the next 10 years they would devote more time to health promotion. That is encouraging and should save us money. That 70 per cent of practitioners said that they would do so even without remuneration. But only 10 per cent were adamant that they would do so if there were no financial remuneration. The importance of a financial incentive is indicated in the same survey's finding that 95 per cent of general practitioners would devote more time to health promotion if it were remunerated adequately. Sixty per cent were adamant about that. There is an overwhelming community expectation that doctors should provide preventive counselling. There is no question about it. The system needs to be adjusted so that preventive medicine is encouraged and made available if we are to reduce costs. That is one of the issues which should be addressed. The report recommends three possible approaches which should be seriously considered. The first recommendation is that a voluntary capitation scheme should be introduced which would enable participating doctors to provide preventive and curative health care with remuneration. Health maintenance organisations are a second recommendation. As seen overseas, they have the potential to provide preventive health care and hospital-based care. Thirdly, the report recommends an increase in the number of salaried medical officers offering preventive health care in community-based health centres.

Health maintenance organisations are receiving a great deal of attention now as a possible addition to the options for provision of health care services. The Government appears to be enthusiastic, but I think we must proceed with caution and not just take the attitude that this system can be transplanted to Australia and almost magically reduce the demand on health care services, reduce costs and build a healthier country. We will need more than that.

Since the release of the Government's discussion paper on HMOs there has been growing public debate, which is to be encouraged. A significant contribution to that debate was made by John Logan of the Centre for Independent Studies in the Australian of 2 October. The critical question is whether HMOs will work in the Australian context and in conjunction with Medicare. A careful evaluation of any HMO-type development will be important. The Government must take an active role in ensuring the quality of care. Quality assurance programs, peer review activities and a consumer complaints mechanism would all be valuable, and the details of just how effectively they would work are important. Some form of licensing or accreditation may be appropriate and some form of consumer control or input to management would certainly be desirable. Monitoring by the Government of financial viability of health maintenance organisations and steps to provide guarantees for enrolees in the event of the financial failure of a fund would also be necessary.

There seems to be no reason why we cannot adopt in our existing system some of the measures used by health maintenance organisations to cut unnecessary hospitalisation, which has been shown to be a major factor in their ability to cut costs overseas. Measures such as compulsory pre-admission review of a range of treatment options for cases other than emergencies and maternity, independent assessment of the need for ongoing hospitalisation and the payment of benefits for a variety of minor procedures, only if they are performed as day surgery on an out-patient basis, ought to be able to be incorporated within the current system. A further requirement in the reduction of hospitalisation periods would have to be an effective system of follow-up care.

The Australian Democrats have always been strong supporters of the third recommendation for the development of community-based health centres. The report refers to community health centres in very positive terms and points out that they generally provide a different approach to health care, especially those with salaried medical officers and support services. A major element in this different approach is the `one-stop' service provision at a community health centre where a range of therapies are available. This is a system which, if developed to its full potential, could play a major role, especially where it promotes and provides access to the full range of therapies and opportunities for counselling towards a more responsible personal approach to health care. The Australian Democrats would also include, as our policy does, the recognition, formal accreditation and increasing integration into the health mainstream of a variety of so-called alternative therapies.

These are some of the suggestions which could take us down the track of saving money and, not incidentally, misery through preventive action. If we can develop a system which encourages and rewards individuals for making sensible and appropriate choices leading to better health, a parallel benefit will certainly be a less slavish belief in the technological quick fix, which again is a big cost in the system. We are now increasingly recognising the impact of the costs of the willy-nilly introduction of new technology. Where high tech options are available, there is a built-in imperative to use them-because they are there, they must be used-with no particular evaluation of the balance between individual benefits against community costs. New technologies quickly supersede each other, causing further additional cost, which falls pretty generally on to the public purse.

Professor Penington, in his paper `Australia's Health Care System-a time for radical change' of April this year showed that, alongside a 20 per cent per patient overall increase in the utilisation of medical services between 1976 and 1983, pathology expanded by 105 per cent and radiology by 55 per cent. In the blow-out of Medicare spending in the last half of 1985, CAT scans increased by 32 per cent and radiology increased by 12.9 per cent over the same period in the previous year. A major challenge is to assess the technologies and to decide which ones are essential and which ones are not justifiable in terms of the scheme's health dollar.

A community which makes better health choices at the individual level will also be less susceptible to the glamour and glitter of the entrepreneurial medical clinic, with its plethora of depersonalised and expensive services, and overservicing would be less of a problem. There are many other challenges. Equitable access to efficient services is the goal, surely, and Medicare is not measuring up. We need to shift the financial incentives to encourage desirable service types at the lowest cost. The interests of health care consumers must come first in an informed environment where people can have a greater influence through access to information on how and which services are provided.

As I indicated when I began, the Australian Democrats will be opposing this Bill because it represents a blatant breach of a firm election promise. As has been the pattern on Budget Bills, we will see token verbal resistance from the Opposition but no real action. However, the Opposition does have an amendment to the second reading motion which, in general terms, the Democrats are able to support as it underlines our attitude to the broken promise on the Medicare levy and our belief, as I have outlined today, that there is a much greater need for much more to be done to reduce growing health care costs. I would be quite disturbed, however, if our support for this amendment should in any way be seen as a lack of support for Medicare. A universal, basic health insurance program is firm Australian Democrats policy and we believe that, in order that it should be a healthy scheme, such actions as we have outlined should be taken, and many others.

It is only now that the real debate on how the system can be changed and can work within that basic principle of universality and quality of care is just beginning. We feel that it takes far more than the throwing out of the baby with the bath water attitude of the Opposition or, indeed, the attitude of the Government that it will continue to drag more and more money into the system to prop it up because it is something which the Government introduced and, again, something which the Democrats supported. The Government does not want to lose face over this and therefore must keep supporting it with money.

We say that there are other ways of changing the system and that we should not simply be wedded to the way the system works now. Perhaps paramount in that is the whole issue of the ability of the Australian people to make better health decisions. As I have said a couple of times this week, I think there is a great deal in the report of the Better Health Commission to guide us in this direction and I hope that the Government and the Parliament in general will accept that report for what it is-a very good guide-post down the road to a more effective and less expensive health care system rather than an expensive illness care system.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Biological Eradication and Control of Pests and Weeds

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 13 June 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What research is currently being undertaken-
(a) by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO); and
under the control of the Minister for Science, relative to the biological eradication or control of:
(2) What research is currently being undertaken-
under the control of the Minister, relative to the biological eradication or control of vegetable weeds in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Before answering each part of the question, it is pointed out that biological control of any pest does not lead to its eradication. Successful biological control, by its nature, leads to a significant reduction in prevalence of a pest to a level below an economic threshold, but small pest populations remain in a dynamic equilibrium with the controlling organisms.

(i) Animal Pests-CSIRO's research on the biological control of animal (vertebrate) pests is directed at the rabbit and the house mouse. In the case of the rabbit, the roles of the myxoma virus and of predators (dingoes, foxes) in controlling rabbit populations are being studied. This work is concentrated in semi-arid regions as the virus has not proved as effective there as in the higher-rainfall regions. The research is aimed at making the best strategic use of myxoma virus in conjunction with the effects of predators and drought on rabbit numbers. In the case of the house mouse, research is aimed at ameliorating the effects of mouse plagues that occur in the wheat-growing areas of southern Australia. Included in this work along with other aspects of the problem is a study of the feasibility of making use of internal parasites (nematodes) as biological control agents. This work is in its early stages.

(ii) Insect Pests-The following research programs of CSIRO are concerned with biological control of insect pests, either directly or through background research relevant to the development of control strategies:
Ecology and Control of Insect Pests of Stored Grain

Aim: To search for new or better methods of controlling stored grain pests. Countries that import Australian grain have come to demand complete freedom from insect infestation. As all the important grain pests have now developed varying degrees of resistance to all pesticides that are fully acceptable internationally for use with stored grain, the need for new control methods is critical.

This program, as well as studying insecticides, is investigating a number of non-insecticidal approaches to grain-pest control. These include high-temperature disinfestation, fumigation, and storage under controlled atmospheres, and the integration of the various control strategies into programs for managing the major pest species.
Ecology and Control of Insect Pests of Crops and Pastures

Aim: To study insects in crop and pasture ecosystems to gain an improved understanding of insect biology, ecology and dispersal, evaluate their pest status, and devise effective and environmentally acceptable measures for their control.
The pests under study include the cotton boll weevil, armyworms, phylloxera of grapes, fruit flies, scale insects, and lucerne aphids.
Ecology and Control of Insect Pests of Trees and Timber
Aim: To study the biology and ecology of insects that damage useful tree species or that attack timber and other materials, and to develop techniques for their control.
Current studies are concerned with the jarrah leaf-miner in Western Australia, the impact of leaf-feeding insects attacking eucalypts in pastoral areas, and with termites.
Ecology and Control of Dung and Dung-breeding Flies
Aim: To determine the major factors influencing the abundance of buffalo fly and bush fly, both of which breed in cattle dung, and to study the ecology of arthropod fauna of dung.

The major objective of the program is to bring about reductions in populations of these flies through biological and other means. A second aim is reduction of dung accumulation in pastures through the introduction of dung-burying beetles.
Ecology and Control of Arthropods Breeding on Livestock

Aim: To study the biology, ecology, behaviour and genetics of flies and other arthropods breeding on livestock with the broad objective of developing management strategies to obtain regional control or eradication of the pest species.
The pests under study are the sheep blowfly, screw-worm fly, and ticks of cattle and other animals.
Insect Pathology

Aim: To study the interactions between disease-causing micro-organisms (including nematodes) and insects in order to develop environmentally acceptable means of pest control; to provide a quarantine service for screening imported insects for pathogens; and to advise on the rearing of disease-free insects.

Pathogenic nematodes have been used to control sirex wood wasp in pine plantations, black currant borer, and black vine weevil. Studies are now focused on pathogenic fungi for the control of aphids, wingless grasshopper, sugar cane grub, banana weevil borer, and rice stem borer.
Insect Behaviour

Aim: To study the behaviour of insects with a view to obtaining biological and chemical information basic to the development of specific and environmentally acceptable pest-control methods, and an understanding of the biology of insects.

Targets of current research include cabbage white butterfly, sheep blowfly, lightbrown apple moth, oriental fruit moth, codling moth, Heliothis species, a number of armyworms, and Queensland fruit fly.
Molecular Genetics of Insects

Aim: To investigate the use of recombinant DNA techniques in the development of novel methods for insect pest control; to study gene organization, expression and regulation in insects; to study evolutionary divergence at the molecular level; and to study the molecular nature of insect development and physiology.
The sheep blowfly program is exploring ways of reducing fly numbers by the release of genetically-modified strains of sheep blowfly.
Insect Taxonomy and General Biology
Aim: To carry out taxonomic research on the Australian insect fauna and research on the general biology of Australian insects.

The correct identification of insect pests and insect predators is crucial to all biological control investigations. Various aspects of insect biology are studies such as the structure and chemistry of cuticles, chemical secretions, nervous and endocrine systems. This helps to explain insect behaviour and resistance to pesticides, and can also indicate weak links that may be exploitable as control measures.
(iii) Fish Pests-CSIRO is not engaged in the biological control of fish pests.
(b) Nil.

(2) (a) CSIRO is actively concerned with the biological control of weeds, either directly or through background research relevant to the development of control strategies. Both terrestrial and aquatic weeds are included. The aim is to study and assess overseas, and subsequently establish in Australia, effective agents for biological control of introduced weeds of economic importance. Current programs are concerned with weeds of European, South African and American origin. They include skeleton weed, heliotrope, St John's wort, ragwort, some of the thistles, spiny emex, mimosa, silver leaf nightshade, salvinia, water hyacinth, and water lettuce.

Research is also carried out on the biology and ecology of weeds. The aim is to contribute to the success of the biological control activities by studying the biological characteristics and ecological relationships of major weeds. The weeds at present under study are skeleton weed and some of the thistles.
(b) Nil.
